Title: Low water levels close Lake Tahoe boat ramps
Description: Lake Tahoe, having been below its natural rim since October 2014, will have fewer boat ramps open during the 2015 summer.  The ramps that are likely to remain closed the entire summer include the popular Sand Harbor ramp, just south of Incline Village; Coon Street on the north shore at Kings Beach, California and on the south shore at El Dorado Beach and Tahoe Vista, California.  The summer boating season typically begins on May 1.San Diego Union-Tribune, April 15, 2015

Title: Congress not eager to address water concerns of group from Fresno, California
Description: Officials and business leaders from the Fresno area embarked on their annual federal lobbying trip to Washington D.C., with the goal of securing aid to improve water supplies during epic drought.  Their meetings were not particularly fruitful where water was concerned as drought and the water supply were apparently seen to be a California issue.  Legislation about California’s water issues did not seem to be an urgent concern to the dismay of the Fresno group.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 14, 2015

Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Wildfire burning in Plumas National Forest in Northern California
Description: The Ward Fire charred 185 acres since it began on April 13 and moved into the Plumas National Forest.  The blaze was driven by winds and compounded by drought.  More than 158 firefighters fought the fire on April 14, trying to get a handle on it before it grew larger.  USA Today, April 15, 2015
Places: Plumas County, CA

Title: Fire agencies increasing staffing early along California's central and southern coast
Description: Along California’s central and southern coasts, fire agencies have upped staffing levels ahead of schedule, due to the exceedingly dry landscape after years of drought.  Ventura County Fire, Santa Barbara County Fire and state fire crews in San Luis Obispo County and the San Benito-Monterey area were bringing in firefighters, fire engines, bull dozers, helicopters and air tankers.  In the Los Padres National Forest, firefighters and equipment were put into place early.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), April 13, 2015
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Orange County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: More water conservation projects in the works for Coachella Valley communities in Southern California
Description: Palm Desert responded to the governor’s call for 25 percent water conservation by curtailing water use in its parks and median landscapes by 25 percent.  The water feature in Joe Mann Park was turned off and will remain so during the summer, saving the city at least 1,500 gallons of water per day, according to the city spokesman.  Irrigation at Civic Center Park is being cut by 10 percent, and all other parks will be watered 25 percent less.  Misting systems will not be used this year, conserving about 100 gallons per hour.The neighboring communities of La Quinta, Cathedral City, Palm Springs and Indio were also making changes to conserve water.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), April 8, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Cathedral City, CA, Indio, CA, La Quinta, CA, Palm Desert, CA, Palm Springs, CA

Title: Possible cuts in water deliveries from Metropolitan Water District in California
Description: The Metropolitan Water District officials will vote next week on cuts in water deliveries to its member agencies and cities.  The reduction in water delivery is anticipated to be in the 10 to 20 percent range.  The MWD serves 19 million Californians.Manteca Bulletin (Calif.), April 7, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Reduced irrigation supplies in the Klamath Reclamation District on the Oregon-California border
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced that irrigators in the Klamath Reclamation District would receive just 65 percent of their full allotment in 2015, due to low snowpack.  The 300-square-mile irrigation district will actually provide 100 percent of requested water to some farmers, while others will get no water on account of the complex maze of irrigation districts, reservoirs and contracts, said a representative of the KRD.  Oregon authorities are not likely to permit additional groundwater pumping to compensate for reduced water deliveries, due to over pumping in recent years.  Farmers are expected to suffer greatly this year.Local wildlife refuges will get no water in 2015, except for those on lands leased to farmers to grow crops, stated a spokesman for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.  This year is the region’s fourth consecutive year of water shortages.The Bulletin (Bend, Ore.), April 9, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Emergency drought salinity barrier in Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta in California
Description: The emergency drought barrier in the West False River between Jersey and Bradford islands was completely dismantled after being installed in May and June to keep saltwater out of the central Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta from San Francisco Bay.  The barrier maintained the water quality in the delta without releasing large amounts of water from upstream reservoirs to flush out salty water.East County Today (Antioch, Calif.), Nov. 17, 2015The California governor’s order announcing mandatory water restrictions also cut red tape for permitting and review of the emergency drought salinity barriers, one of which will be constructed on Bradford Island.  State water officials got the permit from the reclamation board and began surveying, but a supervising engineer with the Department of Water Resources said that building the barrier was not a certainty.  State officials took steps toward the construction of drought barriers in 2014, but significant rainfall made the measure unnecessary. Some locals vehemently oppose the construction of the barrier, fearing Discovery Bay would become a mosquito-infested, stagnant swamp with invasive weed overgrowth.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 12, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Water shortfall in Western Nevada's Carson Valley
Description: Carson Valley irrigators relying on surface water were expected to run short early in 2015 because the Carson River Basin held just 14 percent of average moisture for March and had less than 50 percent of the year to date average.  Some producers will see a second year of no irrigation water.To help agricultural communities cope with the shortage, University of Nevada Cooperative Extension held drought workshops in Gardnerville, Lovelock, Fallon and Yerington in April and May.The Record-Courier (Gardnerville, Nev.), April 3, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alpine County, CA, Churchill County, NV, Douglas County, NV, Lyon County, NV, Pershing County, NV, Storey County, NV

Title: Farm community leaders passionately urge California's Gov. Brown to send more water to the Central Valley
Description: Farm community leaders from Fresno and Tulare counties met in Selma to passionately urge Gov. Brown to send more northern California water to the San Joaquin Valley to keep land in production, keep farmworkers employed and prevent groundwater levels from continuing their rapid decline.  The Tulare County supervisor spoke about the 1,000 domestic well failures, the majority of which were in the eastern part of the county, since the drought began.  He urged the state to create a low-interest loan program to replace unproductive wells, rather than force the families to rely on emergency water deliveries from the county.The Fresno County supervisor mentioned the ramshackle homeless encampment created by unemployed farm laborers on the edge of Mendota.  He stressed the need for water to flow in the valley again to reduce unemployment and described the situation as being “like a Third World country.”The Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 2, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Skiers must climb to reach skiable snow in Sequoia National Park in California
Description: Good skiable snow could be found at 10,000 feet in Sequoia National Park, but it was quite a trek to get there.  Drought and warm temperatures have erased much of the snow at lower levels.Eureka Times-Standard (Calif.), April 2, 2015
Places: Tulare County, CA

Title: Possible regulation on air pollution from fireplaces in the Bay Area of California
Description: The Bay Area Air Quality Management District is considering new regulations to improve air quality because the Bay Area has experienced more Spare the Air days in recent years.  Spare the Air days are called when the amount of particulate matter in the air exceeds standards, prompting the district to prohibit all wood burning.   All Bay Area property owners may need to install federally certified fireplace inserts or wood-burning stoves that filter out fine particles from the chimney.  Drought and the lack of storms has contributed to the poor air quality by not clearing the air of particulate matter.Bay Area Air Quality Management District board members were expected to reach a decision on the issue in the fall of 2015. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 31, 2015
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Nestle targeted for water use in California
Description: Nestle changed its operation and installed new filtration systems at its Modesto plant to reuse wastewater from its condensed milk-making process.  After treating the liquid, it will be used, rather than fresh water, for cleaning and cooling, said Jose Lopez, the company’s head of operations.  “It doesn’t make economic sense to do this, obviously. The drought this year is teaching us you have to think of ways to adapt. What seems today not fully advisable from an economic standpoint will become a necessity,” said Lopez.  Nestle made the change amid very recent criticism of the company’s and other water bottlers' use of California’s freshwater.  In March, protesters with plastic pitchforks blocked gates at Nestle’s water-bottling facility in Sacramento.  More than 82,000 people signed a petition urging Nestle to stop bottling water from a spring in southern California.Washington Post (D.C.), May 13, 2015Nestle has become the target of a group protesting the bottling and sale of Sacramento water for profit.  The leader of the group opposing Nestle termed the company’s bottling of water during the drought as “extremely egregious.”A spokeswoman for Nestle stated that the company purchased roughly 50 million gallons from Sacramento in 2014.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), April 27, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA, Bakersfield, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Sacramento, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Modesto, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tulare, CA

Title: East Bay water customers complain about new taste, odor in water from Pardee Reservoir in California
Description: Some East Bay residents noticed their water had a different taste and odor in late March 2015, and logged more than 200 complaints with the East Bay Municipal Utility District.  The problem began after EBMUD began drawing water from the upper levels of Pardee Reservoir to leave the cooler water near the bottom for use in the fall when salmon spawn in the Mokelumne River.   More algae exist in the upper layers of the water than in the lower levels, giving an earthy taste to the water.  EBMUD was expected to resume pulling water from the deeper parts of the reservoir within a matter of days, which would resolve the issue, although they said the sequence of events could recur again later in the year. San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 30, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Visitor bureaus emphasizing different activities in Yosemite National Park as drought continued to parch the landscape
Description: Visitor bureaus were emphasizing different activities in Yosemite National Park as drought continued to parch the landscape and shrink water sources.  Majestic Yosemite Falls was not highlighted so much, and instead, activities like hiking, biking and photography were recommended to prospective visitors.  Yosemite Falls is expected to run dry in June, two months earlier than usual.  The Merced River, which supplies water to Nevada and Vernal falls, is also anticipated to slow to a trickle in June.  Los Angeles Times, March 28, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Lack of snow allowed opening of road in Yosemite National Park nearly two months early
Description: Glacier Point Road in Yosemite National Park opened March 28, the earliest date in the park’s history as drought and warm temperatures chased away what little snow existed in the park during the winter.  The Sierra Nevada snowpack measurement in March showed historical or near-historical lows.Los Angeles Times, March 28, 2015
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: California salmon being trucked to Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta again
Description: Twelve million juvenile Chinook salmon are being trucked from the Coleman National Fish Hatchery in Anderson to Rio Vista in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta because the warm flow of Battle Creek, a tributary of the Sacramento River, is very low.  The 3-inch long smolts would likely perish before they reach the delta, leaving very few to return as adults to reproduce in three years.  Six trucks will take approximately 22 working days to deliver the fish to the delta, with the project planned to be finished by mid-May.Salmon were transported to the delta in the spring of 2014, as well, because there was too little water to allow safe passage to the delta.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 26, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Solano County, CA, Rio Vista, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Temporary water release from Folsom Lake in California to protect endangered steelhead
Description: As endangered steelhead trout in the American River prepare to hatch, the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation decreased water releases from Folsom Dam to 500 cubic feet per second on March 26.  This flow is below a negotiated standard agreed to by the Water Forum to protect the river environment, but allowable during periods of severe drought.The outflow was temporarily increased through gates in the dam’s face to draw out cold water from deeper parts of the reservoir to cool water in the American River for the nearly hatched fish.  The release will end on the afternoon of March 30.  The brevity of the water release underscored the importance of conserving the region's precious water.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 29, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sacramento County, CA

Title: Minor tweaks to water restrictions in southern Orange County, California
Description: In much of southern Orange County, water restrictions will change little, despite the State Water Resources Control Board’s updates to the statewide water regulations.  Restrictions in southern Orange County were already rather strict and mostly in line with many of the SWRCB's updates, due to the adoption of more stringent restrictions during the 2014 summer.  The area’s scarce groundwater supply and reliance on water imported from Northern California and the Colorado River also increased the need for water conservation.The El Toro Water District discussed amending an ordinance to prohibit irrigation during rain and for 48 hours afterward to be in line with the new state water restrictions.  The district was also considering tightening each household’s water budget to promote more conservation if the Metropolitan Water District reduces supplies for its members.  The Santa Margarita might adopt a higher level of drought emergency plan, given the severity and length of the drought, according to the district spokesman.Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), March 25, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Orange County, CA

Title: Economy crimped by high water prices, reduced ag production in Kern County, California
Description: Drought and unusually low oil prices have taken a toll on Kern County’s economy, with agricultural output and oil profits falling.   An economist from Cal State Bakersfield stated that the county could lose 7,000 jobs in oil, agriculture and related industries.  Local water experts feared that the amount of land in agricultural production could drop by one-fifth as the cost of water rises due to scarcity and could result in the loss of 12,400 farm jobs and $631 million annually in income to farmers.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), March 25, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: California's Sierra Nevada ski resorts offering activities geared toward less snowy winters
Description: As the snow drought drove numerous West Coast resorts to close early, many Sierra Nevada resorts were adapting by offering more warm weather activities and events to keep visitors entertained and busy while visiting the resorts year round.  Some Sierra Nevada resorts were constructing zip lines, mountain bike trails and wedding venues to adapt to less snowy winters and to continue to draw visitors.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 22, 2015

Title: Allergy season longer, more severe in California's Bay Area
Description: The allergy season began earlier than normal in the Bay Area, and drought could prolong allergy symptoms, say allergists.  When there is no rain to wash the pollen out of the air, the pollen continues to be blown around by the wind, possibly extending the allergy season.  In addition, the amount of pollen in the air is higher than usual.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 19, 2015

Title: Private groundwater use data to remain private in Riverside County, California
Description: The Coachella Valley Water District does not have to reveal private customers' groundwater use data, ruled a Riverside County Superior Court judge.  The First Amendment Coalition sued the CVWD and the Desert Water Agency for access to the records of businesses, such as golf courses.  The executive director of the First Amendment Coalition described the concealing of usage information during a drought as offensive.The CVWD and Desert Water Agency stopped sharing such information after The Desert Sun published a list of biggest groundwater consumers, most of which were commercial or industrial, in March 2014.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), March 18, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Count of delta smelt in California's Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta at record low
Description: A March survey of Delta smelt found just six fish, the smallest March count ever recorded, according to environmental groups and scientists.  Drought and delta water diversion were blamed for the population collapse, which may lead to extinction of the species.  An emergency ruling easing environmental requirements in February and March permitted water releases to lessen salinity in the delta, but environmentalists claim the releases further harmed the small fish.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 17, 2015

Title: Private boat launches closed at Diamond Valley Lake in Southern California
Description: The boat ramps at Diamond Valley Lake remained unusable, due to low water levels.  The extended boat ramp was also above the water, but inflows to the lake should allow the use of boat ramps in mid-May 2016.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), April 26, 2016The Metropolitan Water District approved a $500,000 project to extend the boat ramp at Diamond Valley Lake after low water levels forced the closure of the ramp in April.  The three middle lanes will be lengthened 120 feet to an elevation of 1,640 feet.  In July, the ramp’s final design should be done, and the project should be completed in November. The lake has fallen to 46 percent of capacity and may reach the lowest level since MWD filled the lake more than 15 years ago.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 12, 2015Private boat launches at Diamond Valley Lake closed on April 15 as the water level fell to 390,000 acre-feet or 48 percent of the lake’s 810,000 acre-feet capacity.  The lake is regarded as one of the premiere fishing spots in Southern California and is still open to shore fishing and boat rentals.   Metropolitan Water District operates the man-made reservoir which was opened for fishing in 2003.  Low water levels in 2008 and 2009 also resulted in the closure of private boat ramps.    Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), April 15, 2015Private boat launches at Diamond Valley Lake will not be in use after April 15, announced the Metropolitan Water District on March 17.  The lake has a capacity of 810,000 acre-feet, but the lake held 390,000 acre-feet or 48 percent of capacity at mid-March.  During the past 14 months, MWD drained 193,000 acre-feet from lake, dropping the water level 44 feet.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), March 17, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Landscape in Madera County, California drastically altered by drought
Description: On a Madera County ranch, bull pine trees were dying from lack of moisture.  Grass was very short when it should have been knee high.  Vegetation that would normally stay green through the end of May was already brown.  A spring that used to flow had dried up, and a pond serving the ranch since the 1940s was dry.  Just 150 cattle of the former herd of 600 remained on the ranch after years of drought.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 14, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Madera County, CA, O'Neals, CA

Title: Some water-conscious Californians do not appreciate high income of several Bay Area water agencies' general managers
Description: Some water-conscious Californians, threatened with rising water costs, do not appreciate that general managers of several Bay Area water agencies earn as much as $445,000 annually.   Pressed to conserve more water, residents also resent that water agencies raise water rates because revenue does not cover fixed costs, while giving bonuses and pay raises to top executives.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 14, 2015

Title: Ski resorts closing early around Lake Tahoe
Description: Sugar Bowl Ski Resort has surrendered to the dry winter, making it the sixth ski resort to close early.  Other closed resorts include Donner Summit, Sierra-at-Tahoe, Donner Ski Ranch, Homewood, Soda Springs and Tahoe Donner.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 19, 2015Sierra-at-Tahoe Resort closed on March 16, due to warm temperatures and insufficient snowpack, but would reopen if enough snow falls.  The resort normally stays open into April, but could not maintain up to their standard.   About 220 employees were affected by the resort’s closing.  If the resort does not reopen before the end of the season, this would be the earliest closing since the 1970s, said a spokeswoman.Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), March 16, 2015Several 7,200-feet ski resorts, such as Soda Springs, Donner Ski Ranch and Royal Gorge were closed for lack of snow.  At Kingvale, about 1,000 feet lower, melting patches of snow facilitated some sledding.  The lift to the top of the bunny slope was not operating.   The Homewood Ski Resort closed early after warm temperatures and scant snowfall in January and February.  A Kingvale employee explained that everyone relying on winter activities for employment was struggling.  Ski instructors and lift operators have been laid off.  Conversely, those doing working construction building roads and houses were busy.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 14, 2015

Title: Water purchase to ensure adequate supplies for the Dublin San Ramon Services District in California
Description: The Dublin San Ramon Services District plans to buy 1,500 acre-feet of water from Yuba County Water Agency and East Bay Municipal Utility District to prevent water shortages in the DSRSD.Pleasanton Weekly (Calif.), March 13, 2015

Title: Metropolitan Water District of Southern California buying Sacramento Valley water
Description: Some SoCal water districts, including the Metropolitan Water District, have purchased 115,000 acre-feet of water from rice farmers in the Sacramento Valley at a cost of $71 million.  Some of the farmers find selling the water to be more lucrative than growing rice, but rice production was already down 25 percent in 2014 for lack of water.This water transaction and others are indicative of the market forces shifting water allocations in California. The Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 12, 2015

Title: California's East Bay Municipal Utility District considering voluntary water restrictions
Description: Customers of the East Bay Municipal Utility District may be asked to use 20 percent less water, an increase from the current goal of 15 percent water conservation, after the EBMUD general manager brought the recommendation to the board.  District managers proposed that overuse penalty fees be assessed on households that use more than 1,476 gallons per day.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 25, 2015East Bay Municipal Utility District board members received an update on water supplies and learned that reservoirs in the Sierra were at their lowest in 40 years, or about the same volume as during the 1977 drought.  Overall, the Sierra snowpack was at 19 percent of normal, while the snowpack in the Mokelumne Basin, which the district relies upon for runoff, was at 17 percent of normal.  The district was considering asking its customers to voluntarily cut their water use by 15 percent.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 10, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Possible water rate hikes for customers in California's Bay Area
Description: East Bay Municipal Water District customers may see a 25 percent surcharge on their bills to cover additional drought-related costs, including $55 million to deliver an emergency supply from the Sacramento River.  The water board will likely vote on the surcharge on June 9.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 25, 2015The Santa Clara Valley Water District was backing away somewhat from its proposal to raise water rates by 31 percent and was suggesting an increase of 19 percent as public backlash and skepticism of board members led to another discussion of the proposal.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 11, 2015Three large Bay Area water providers—the Santa Clara Valley Water District, the East Bay Municipal Utility District and the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission –are considering raising water rates by as much as 30 percent to compensate for reduced revenue.  Customers are conserving water, and agencies have had to find alternate supplies when usual water providers could not deliver contracted water.  Other additional expenses include expanding public relations budgets to persuade the public to conserve and offering rebates for replacing turf or installing water-efficient appliances.  Some people are livid about the rate increases, while others think that people will use less water if it costs more.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 7, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Drought complicating plan to take down section of San Francisco Bay Bridge
Description: Caltran’s plan to take down the old eastern span of the San Francisco Bay Bridge has run into an obstacle.  Drought-related low flows have dropped the longfin smelt population to an historic low in the San Francisco Bay, leading the state to list it as an endangered species in 2009.  The quickest, least expensive method of dismantling the bridge is to blow it up, but such an event would likely be devastating to the fragile little fish.  If Caltrans chooses another bridge removal option, slower but less harmful to the fish, the job may not be completed before cormorants return to nest, which may put Caltrans in violation of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act and the California Fish and Game code.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 7, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Marin County, CA, San Francisco County, CA

Title: Pine bark beetles wreaking havoc in Bear Valley, California
Description: Trees in High Country Park in Bear Valley are infested with pine bark beetles and were to be dealt with immediately.  Of the roughly 900 trees in the park, 219 were affected, while 164 were actively infested.  The beetles often attack weakened or distressed trees affected by drought.  Years of drought has worsened the infestation, which has spread quickly.Bakersfield Californian, March 6, 2015
Places: Alpine County, CA, Midpines, CA

Title: Review of Nestle's water permit to take water from San Bernardino National Forest in California
Description: Nestle has been pumping and bottling spring water from the San Bernardino National Forest on a water permit that expired in 1988, an issue that was uncovered by a Desert Sun investigation into water bottlers in California amid the drought.  The U.S. Forest Service has begun the renewal process for the permit and will soon begin accepting public comments.  An environmental review of the water withdrawal has not been done, which has critics of the water company and its sales suing the Forest Service, asserting it has violated the law by allowing the company to take water from the national forest without a valid permit.The Desert Sun (Palm Springs, Calif.), Dec. 16, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Limited work opportunities, drought drive need for food, utility assistance in California's San Joaquin Valley
Description: The variability of seasonal employment and drought has sapped work opportunities and limited monthly income for workers in the San Joaquin Valley.  Consequently, the Fresno Economics Opportunities Commission has been helping more people with utility bills.  On an average day, more than 100 people seek one-time energy assistance, with more first-time applicants looking for a helping hand than in previous years.  An EOC representative described aid applicants as being emotional and embarrassed at being unemployed and needing assistance.  The Community Food Bank, serving residents in Fresno, Kern, Kings, Madera and Tulare counties, provides food assistance to 280,000 people monthly.  The director of development at the food bank estimated that 15,000 people were directly affected by the drought.  The Salvation Army also offers help with utility bills through Reach for Energy Assistance with Community Help, a utility assistance program offered through Pacific Gas & Electric Co.  Each day, 50 to 85 people ask for help with utility bills.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 4, 2015
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Farmers may receive no water from Merced Irrigation District in California
Description: The Merced Irrigation District has no water to offer farmers from Lake McClure, which was at 8 percent of capacity.  When the lake falls below 11.5 percent of capacity, under state and federal regulations, no water can be diverted for irrigation.  The district intends to pump less than 60,000 acre-feet from its wells for farmers’ use, which is a drop in the bucket, considering that the district’s 2,200 growers usually receive 300,000 to 400,000 acre-feet from Lake McClure.The Modesto Bee (Calif.), March 3, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Merced County, CA

Title: Water table too low to sustain arroyo toads in San Diego County, California
Description: Arroyo toads in San Diego County did not survive the fourth consecutive dry winter.  The low water table did not keep the toads moist through the winter because it had fallen after years of drought.  Ecologists with the U.S. Geological Survey had attached radio transmitters to the amphibians to monitor their movements and came looking for the toads when they remained still in their 4-foot-deep dens in the spring.  Toads living in the drier desert slopes of the San Bernardino and San Gabriel mountain ranges also fared badly.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Aug. 21, 2015
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Rice acreage reduced due to water shortage in Sutter County, California
Description: A Sutter County rice grower fallowed 30 percent of his acreage in 2015 because the South Sutter Water District warned growers that allocations from the Far West Reservoir would be about half of normal.  Drought, however, improved the rice’s overall texture.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Nov. 2, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sutter County, CA

Title: Only one Delta smelt found in survey of California's Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: The March trawl survey for adult smelt conducted by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife found only four females and two males in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.  The April survey turned up just one fish.  Counts of longfin smelt had also fallen to record lows.  Early in April, the State Water Resources Board chose to limit Sierra runoff to the estuary, due to drought, depriving fish of the cold, fresh water that enhances survival.  Among the threats to the smelt are water being pumped from the delta, increased salinity in the fall, improved water clarity in the summer and fall and competition and predation from introduced species, according to California Fish and Wildlife.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 15, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: California's Central Valley Project offered initial allocation of zero percent; urban areas, 25 percent
Description: The initial allocation for the Central Valley Project was zero percent for most Central Valley farmers as the Sierra Nevada snowpack remained thin.  This is a nightmare for CVP farmers who received no water in 2014.  The storms that have come through the state have been warm, leaving little snow in the Sierra Nevada to fill CVP reservoirs.Urban areas, such as Santa Clara, Alameda and Contra Costa counties, were told to expect 25 percent of contracted amounts.Central Valley Business Times (Stockton, Calif.), Feb. 27, 2015 and San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Feb. 27, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Stricter water conservation for Santa Clara Valley Water District in California
Description: Santa Clara Valley Water District customers must lower their water use by 30 percent and water their lawns no more than twice weekly as groundwater reserves remained low.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 25, 2015The Santa Clara Valley Water District is considering asking water customers to curb water use by 30 percent and allowing lawn watering just twice weekly.  The move toward more stringent water restrictions comes after an analysis showed that Silicon Valley groundwater reserves did not benefit much from above-average seasonal rain.  The water board hoped that its retailers will follow suit and strive for more water conservation.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 23, 2015The Santa Clara Valley Water District is considering stricter water conservation measures, including harsh limits on lawn watering and the advent of fines for scofflaws.  Rebates for turf removal and the installation of water-efficient fixtures may also be in the offing.  These options will be discussed at the March 24 meeting.  To compensate for decreased rainfall, the district has been relying heavily on groundwater, resulting in a water table drop of 60 feet under San Jose during the past three years. San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Feb. 27, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Water rates to discourage excessive water use in Contra Costa Water District in California
Description: The Contra Costa Water District is considering raising its fee for excessive water use when the board meets in April.  In place of doubling the cost of water for households that use more than 1,000 gallons daily, the cost may go even higher.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Feb. 27, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Conflict over water withdrawals in Kern County, California
Description: The Kern County Water Agency wants to connect to its 42nd well and pump water to the Kern River Canal for agricultural use, but the city of Bakersfield also pumps water in the vicinity between KCWA’s wells.  Officials for Bakersfield would like the agency to wait until the drought eases before drawing water from their 42nd well, feeling that granting the agency’s water withdrawal request would not be in the city’s best interest.The KCWA claims to have 550,000 acre-feet of water banked and wants to be able to access what they have paid for.  Alternative options may exist for the KCWA to get its water. Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Feb. 20, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: High groundwater use in the Santa Clara Valley Water District in California in 2014
Description: Groundwater withdrawals in the Santa Clara Valley Water District during 2014 amounted to nearly 84,000 acre-feet, said a District 3 Santa Clara Valley Water District representative, exceeding groundwater use in 2013.  The district’s 10 reservoirs only hold 68,000 acre-feet or about 81 percent of what was used in 2014.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Feb. 19, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Truckee River in western Nevada stocked with fish early while enough water still flowed
Description: Low water in the Truckee River persuaded the Nevada Department of Wildlife to stock the river with 7,000 rainbow trout earlier than normal while there is still enough water in the river to support the fish.  Lake Tahoe remained 2.5 inches below its natural rim, in spite of the recent storms that caused an inflow of roughly 16 billion gallons of water.  The snowpack in the Truckee River basin was less than 50 percent of normal for this time of year.Fish were stocked in February last year—the earliest in 20 years—also due to drought and low river flows.Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Feb. 12, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alpine County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Carson City, NV, Churchill County, NV, Douglas County, NV, Pershing County, NV, Storey County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Lack of snow forces cancellation of ski and snowboard competitions at Squaw Valley resort in Sierra Nevada of California
Description: The lack of snow at Squaw Valley resort in Placer County led to the cancellation of the World Cup skicross and snowboardcross races on March 4-8.  The area has received just 140 inches of snow this winter, but normally gets an annual average of 450 inches.  The U.S. Ski and Snowboard Association’s Hole Shot NorAm and U.S. Revolution Tour skicross and snowboardcross to be held on March 9-13, has also been cancelled.  Officials were looking for another venue for the event.Tahoe Daily Tribune (Calif.), Feb. 14, 2015
Places: Placer County, CA

Title: Firefall absent in California's Yosemite National Park
Description: Drought conditions prevented Horsetail Fall in Yosemite National Park from flowing, meaning that the February firefall was not there.  During a two-week period in February when the fall is flowing, the sun angle at sunset is just right to illuminate the water, creating the appearance of lava.
Places: Mariposa County, CA

Title: Army Black Hawk helicopters practiced water drops ahead of the California firefighting season
Description: Army Black Hawk helicopters practiced water drops ahead of the firefighting season in southern California, said Cal Fire officials.  "With California still in the grips of a history-making drought, the possibility of larger, more devastating wildfires exists and the military plays a key role in these large incidents," said Cal Fire officials in a written statement.In light of the meager rainfall and limited water supplies in southern California, the Army reservists drew water from a reclaimed water storage pond and returned the water to the same pond to avoid wasting the precious liquid.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Feb. 9, 2015; Feb. 11, 2015
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Winchester, CA

Title: Measure to increase water-wasting fines in the works for unincorporated parts of Los Angeles County, California
Description: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors gave preliminary approval to a measure that would increase water-wasting fines from $100 to $500 for each offense in unincorporated parts of the county.  The measure must get final approval before it takes effect.  Towns affected include Altadena, Lennox and Del Aire near LAX, Rancho Dominguez in the South Bay and View Park, Windsor Hills and Baldwin Hills north of Inglewood.The fine increase would make the county compliant with state conservation efforts.Los Angeles Times, Feb. 10, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Water cutbacks of 15 percent for customers of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California
Description: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California will reduce water deliveries by 15 percent starting in July 2015 as a fourth year of drought continues to limit the state’s water resources.  Communities are expected to curb water use rather than pay high prices for water above the allotted amount.  If cities must purchase additional water, the price will be at least four times the usual price.  The delivery cut will be reassessed in December to decide if changes are warranted.  The MWD provides water to 19 million people and more than two dozen water agencies in southern California.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), April 15, 2015The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California informed its customers that water cutbacks of 5 to 10 percent could be in the offing this summer, barring significant precipitation.  The MWD may have to make “significant withdrawals” from its reservoirs if the next few months remain dry, although those reservoirs hold less than 50 percent of the water they held at the end of 2012.  A decision on the water cutbacks will come at an April meeting and will begin in July if approved.Los Angeles Times, Feb. 10, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Wildfire on border of Mono and Inyo counties in California fed on dry trees after years of drought
Description: An 11 square mile wildfire on the border of Mono and Inyo counties consumed 40 homes after the wind-driven blaze roared out of control on Feb. 6.  The town of Swall Meadows lost 39 homes, while just one home burned in Paradise.  A captain with the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection said that the three year drought has dried out trees and vegetation, creating plenty of fuel that fed the fire up the Sierra slopes to the snow line at 8,000 feet.Portland Oregonian, Hillsboro Argus, Oregon Live.com (Ore.), Feb. 8, 2015
Places: Inyo County, CA, Mono County, CA

Title: Snowmobilers asked to avoid damaging land, vegetation around Lake Tahoe
Description: The U.S. Forest Service is asking snowmobilers in the Lake Tahoe Basin to avoid bare dirt and patchy snow, not to cross streams and not to drive over small trees and brush.  These actions make ruts in the soil and damage vegetation.  Warm temperatures and low snowfall have created unusual winter conditions.Capital Public Radio (Sacramento, Calif.), Feb 5. 2015
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Water diverters in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta required to provide proof of water rights
Description: The Department of Water Resources and U.S. Bureau of Reclamation complained that large amounts of water continued to disappear from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta amid prolonged drought when every drop of water was in high demand.  The state began investigating and suspect farmers in the delta area were taking the water for irrigation.  The farmers say that indeed they are taking water to which they have senior water rights, having lived along the water’s edge for generations.  The state has asked them to provide information on water use and proof of their water rights.  The delta farmers felt that Central Valley farmers should know that they would receive less water during dry years and should pump groundwater to continue growing crops.Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), April 12, 2015The State Water Resources Control Board (SWRCB) ordered 1,061 property owners within the Sacramento and San Joaquin River watersheds on Feb. 4 to offer proof of their water rights.  In July 2014, the California Department of Water Resources and U.S. Bureau of Reclamation claimed that south and central Delta diverters were taking more than their water rights allowed.  The DWR and Reclamation urged the SWRCB to ask for proof of water rights or the diverters must face curtailment.  The proof must be submitted by March 6.  This situation is representative of the scramble for water resources as they become scarcer.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 1, 2015

Title: CA water board  denied request to send more Northern California river water south;  pumping for irrigation not allowed in SoCal
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board denied a joint state and federal request to send more Northern California river water south of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, despite approval of the request by state and federal wildlife and water agencies.House majority leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Bakersfield, termed the denial “a stunning rebuke of common sense.”  He and other Valley elected leaders demand that the SWRCB reverse their decision.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Feb. 14, 2015The Kern County Water Agency expressed shock that the State Water Resources Control Board (SWRCB) approved only parts of the Temporary Urgency Change Petition filed by the California Department of Water Resources and the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation.  Recipients of water from the State Water Project from San Jose to San Diego may pump enough water for minimum public health and safety requirements, but not for agriculture during February and March.  KGET-TV (Bakersfield, Calif.), Feb. 4, 2015

Title: Low per capita water use in North Coast of California
Description: Some California residents in the North Coast region faced mandatory water restrictions requiring a cut of 50 percent and achieved some of the lowest per capita water usages in the state.  Redwood Valley residents, for example,  must use no more than 50 gallons daily.Los Angeles Times, Feb. 2, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Trinity County, CA

Title: Some families in East Porterville, California using potentially contaminated well water, despite the health risks
Description: Some families with dry wells in East Porterville have depended on water deliveries for so long that it has taken an emotional toll on relationships between spouses and children.  Some families have resorted to using what little water their pumps can draw, despite warnings that the water was contaminated with high levels of nitrates from leaking septic tanks and farm fertilizer runoff.  Tulare County officials have distributed bottled water and large 3,000-gallon water tanks purchased with emergency funds from the state, but the need is so great that water delivery trucks cannot always return weekly to refill tanks, sometimes leaving families without water on the weekends or over holidays.In addition to being without water, many families were struggling financially because there were fewer farm jobs available.The Washington Post (D.C.), Feb. 13, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA, East Porterville, CA

Title: Fewer hotel bookings in Tahoe-area due to thin snowpack
Description: The thin snowpack in the Sierra Nevada has Tahoe-area hotels seeing fewer guests.  Bookings were good at the start of the season, but the poor snow condition led to fewer bookings than usual since February, said tourism officials.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 19, 2015
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Water recipients of the North Bay Aqueduct in Napa County, California may receive 25 percent from the State Water Project
Description: Water recipients of the North Bay Aqueduct were told they could receive 25 percent of their full allotment from the State Water Project.  The allocation estimate could change based on subsequent rainfall or lack of it.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Jan. 29, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Napa County, CA, American Canyon, CA, Napa, CA

Title: Monterey County, California curbing water use
Description: Monterey County automatic irrigation systems were turned off to conserve water, and water use fell by about 50 percent.  County employees’ water conservation efforts were being tracked to encourage conservation on and off the job.  Internal and inter-agency drought task forces were scheduling February and March meetings to come up with responses to drought impacts.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 28, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Monterey County, CA

Title: California irrigation districts reunite after water supply recovered
Description: Madera Irrigation District and Hills Valley Irrigation District rejoined Friant Water Authority, the agency that operates and maintains the Friant-Kern Canal.  Madera left Friant two years ago when Friant Division contractors received no water from the Central Valley Project, due to drought.  The reunification made the Friant Water Authority the largest part of the Friant Division federal water contractors in terms of acreage and amount of water.  The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Jan. 26, 2017
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Madera County, CA

Title: California land with water rising in value
Description: The value of land with wells has risen in the Paso Robles area and also in Sonoma and Napa counties.  Irrigable land in the Paso Robles area was selling for $15,000 to $20,000 per acre, compared to $3,000 for an acre of dry pasture.  The price for irrigable land has increased dramatically during drought and is expected to climb as investors from Napa Valley and Sonoma look for good land, according to an analysis by the real estate investment company Pacifica Real Estate Group.  The cost of land in the Napa Valley and Sonoma ranges from $75,000 to $100,000 per acre.  Reuters, Jan. 22, 2015
Places: Napa County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Paso Robles, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Weeds clogging California's Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: Weeds proliferated in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, clogging harbors, trapping boats in their slips, hindering cargo deliveries, endangering migrating birds and jeopardizing the safety of those who navigate the waters.  Drought is responsible for conditions conducive to the growth of water hyacinth and other weeds.  With a smaller Sierra snowpack, less cold water enters the Delta, leaving smaller amounts of warmer than usual water flowing into the Delta.  The decreased water flows are not strong enough to push the weeds out of the river to the ocean.  Efforts to control the weeds are inadequate because water hyacinths drop as many as 5,000 seeds per plant that can remain viable for up to 20 years.San Jose Mercury-News (Calif.), Jan. 21, 2015

Title: Ski resort closed in Nevada County, California due to lack of snow
Description: A lack of snow led Tahoe Donner Cross Country near Truckee to close until the area receives more snowfall.  A spokeswoman for the ski resort said they tried to keep trails and snowshoeing areas suitable for use, but without snow, there is little they can do.   All programs, clinics and events are postponed until conditions improve.  Unfortunately, forecasters predict that drought will likely persist or worsen in coming months, taking the region into its fourth year of drought.Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Jan. 21, 2015
Places: Nevada County, CA

Title: Less water sharing in the Santa Cruz mountains of California
Description: Small water companies in the Santa Cruz mountains asked the Loma Prieta volunteer fire department to find water elsewhere because the drought has reduced water supplies, leading the water companies to protect their own water resources.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 21, 2015

Title: Numerous ski resorts lack sufficient snow to open, remain operational in California, western Nevada
Description: Badger Pass resort in Yosemite National Park remained closed due to the snow drought.  The Ostrander Lake ski hut closed on Feb. 2.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Feb. 27, 2015The snow drought in the Sierra Nevada has hurt resorts of all sizes as warm temperatures led to rain rather than coveted snow.  The President’s Day weekend is typically the busiest weekend for skiing, but many resorts were closed.seattlepi.com (Wash.), Feb. 13, 2015The Dodge Ridge ski resort in Tuolumne County and Badger Pass ski resort in Yosemite National Park shut down their ski lifts due to the lack of snow and will reopen them when the snow situation improves. Title: Central California Red Cross began preparing for 2015 fire season early
Description: Foreseeing another challenging fire season, the Central California region of the American Red Cross began preparing in January.  They began lining up volunteers, sponsors and grants to be ready for an intense year when drought conditions lead to more wildfires and greater demand for Red Cross services.Emergency Management (Folsom, Calif.), July 12, 2015

Title: Appeals for the movement of more water through the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta in California refused
Description: Appeals by Central Valley farmers and California water districts wanting to pull more water from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta were brought to the U.S. Supreme Court and refused.  A 2008 U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service plan to protect Delta smelt, a threatened species, still stands and limits the amount of water that can be drawn from the delta for the use of Central Valley farmers and water districts.   Farmers feel that the fishes’ protection prevents them from getting water needed to irrigate their crops and creates hardships on top of those created by the ongoing drought.  The farmers also think their economic interests were being ignored.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 12, 2015

Title: Oak trees in California's Central Coast suffering in drought
Description: The signature oak trees of the Central California Coast were showing signs of drought stress and an estimated of 2 to 3 percent of the trees were dying, said an oak rangeland specialist with the UC Cooperative Extension in San Luis Obispo County.  Trees on shallow soil or that face south were especially at risk.  Residents have noted trees that were halfway out of the ground or that were dead.  Old trees and those with oak worm were particularly vulnerable.  Reduced acorn production, due to drought, has left deer with less to eat in preparation for the winter.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Jan. 9, 2015
Places: Monterey County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA

Title: Some sequoia trees in Giant Forest, east of Fresno, California, have more brown patches
Description: Since the start of 2015, 490 trees died on a 2 ½-acre plot in Sequoia National Park, noted a research ecologist with the U.S. Geological Survey.  In comparison, 50 trees, including a mix of sugar and ponderosa pine, incense cedar, white fir and oak, in the same plot died in 2010.  The sequoia trees in Giant Forest were being monitored to better determine how drought might be affecting the massive trees.  While some sequoias had brown leaves, most of the trees appeared to be doing well, despite the drought.  Populations of young sequoias appeared to be healthy.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Aug. 28, 2015

Title: Donations to Food Bank down in Napa Valley, California
Description: Donations of food and money at the Community Action Napa Valley’s Food Bank fell drastically in 2015.  The food bank received 64,756 pounds of donated food in 2014, but in 2015, donations fell 52.2 percent to 30,909 pounds.  Monetary donations have fallen off, too, from $483,142 in 2014 to $383,310 in 2015.  Napa Valley Register (Calif.), March 16, 2016

Title: California farm revenue down more than $9 billion in 2015
Description: California farm revenue fell by more than $9 billion in 2015 while drought limited irrigation water supplies and critical commodities, such as milk and tree nuts, decreased in price, according to data from the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s economic research service and the California Department of Food and Agriculture.  Farm income totaled $47.07 billion in 2015, and was a record $56.61 billion in 2014.  Farmers have coped with less water from state and federal projects by pumping groundwater and planting more lucrative crops like almonds.  Farmers also fallowed 540,000 acres in 2015 as they anticipated not having enough water.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 31, 2016

Title: Loggers thronging to fell California's millions of dead trees
Description: Roughly 102 million dead trees in California, needing to be felled for safety’s sake, lured loggers from across the nation, looking for steady work and a good paycheck.  Loggers began arriving in 2015 as the U.S. Forest Service reported 66 million dead trees, and the estimated numbers of dead trees has continued to climb.  The employment opportunity has also led some loggers to move their families from places like Oregon and Georgia because the work will last a while.  Along with an emergency order, Gov. Jerry Brown in 2016 pledged tens of millions of dollars to remove the dead trees, and the influx of loggers began.  At least six public and private agencies were paying to have the trees removed and turned into biofuel or into chips for emergency offramps to slow runaway trucks.  The California Department of Transportation set aside $11 million to get rid of the trees before they fall and impede traffic to and from Yosemite National Park or hurt a motorist.  In January, CalTrans had 30,000 trees designated for removal along State Routes 41 and 168.  The agency paid as much as $1,000 per tree and already paid about $6.5 million for the removal of about 8,000 trees.  The Forest Service and two utilities, Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas and Electric, were also spending millions to get rid of the trees.  The Washington Post (D.C.), Feb. 6, 2017
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: California, Fresno County, CA, Clovis, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: High demand for water-saving equipment, tools and technology in California
Description: Central Valley companies and entrepreneurs offering water-saving equipment, tools and technology were enjoying high demand for their services.  The owner of a synthetic lawn installation business reported an 81 percent increase in sales since the start of the year, compared to the previous year.  They also were booked through the latter part of September and hired four additional workers to meet demand.  The sales of showerheads, lawn paint, landscape rocks, drought-tolerant plants, rain barrels and similar items were all through the roof.  The Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 20, 2015

Title: Wine grape production down in San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: Wine grape production in San Luis Obispo County fell by 31 percent in 2015, due to cool, windy spring temperatures and ongoing drought.  Total crop value in 2015 was $828.8 million, down 8 percent from 2014.  The values of avocados, walnuts and cattle sold also declined.San Luis Obispo County Tribune (Calif.), May 10, 2016
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Drought hurting inland water quality in San Diego County, California
Description: San Diego County’s inland water quality deteriorated in 2015 due to the drought, according to a new San Diego Coastkeeper report that discovered high bacteria counts and low levels of oxygen in the region’s creeks and streams.  The county’s inland water quality ranged from fair to poor, with no watersheds receiving a “good” or “excellent” rating.  Northern watersheds earned “fair” ratings, while most central and southern watersheds were “marginal.”  The Tijuana area was considered “poor.”  The most worrisome results from the sample testing were the fecal indicator bacteria, including E. coli and enterococcus bacteria, which point to possible water contamination.  These common bacteria can signal the presence of other harmful microorganisms that can cause ailments among swimmers.   Los Angeles Times, May 12, 2016
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Drought cut into crop values for Solano County, California
Description: The gross value of Solano County’s agricultural production for 2015 was $353,869,000, representing a decrease from 2014 values by $24,776,000 or a 6.5 percent drop. The number of head for sheep and lambs dropped to 29,700 from 32,950 in 2014 and the total value dropped to $6,684,000 from $7,912,000 in 2014, a difference of 16 percent as producers shipped lambs earlier at lighter weights, due to drought.  Vacaville Reporter (Calif.), June 11, 2016
Places: Solano County, CA

Title: Drought, bark beetles responsible for many trees deaths in California's national forests
Description: Roughly 570,000 dead trees on 160,000 acres were lost to drought and bark beetles in the Shasta-Trinity National Forest, according to a 2015 survey.  The Lassen National Forest had lost about 831,000 trees over 165,000 acres, and the Klamath National Forest had an estimated 350,000 dead trees over 70,000 acres from the same causes. Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), June 19, 2016

Title: Drought among factors lowering Fresno County, California's ag production
Description: Fresno County’s ag production was valued at $6.61 billion in 2015, down 6 percent from the previous year.  The county’s top five crops are almonds, grapes, poultry, cattle and calves, and tomatoes, and production of all five was lower in 2015.  Fresno County Ag Commissioner Les Wright noted, “There are many factors contributing to these declines. A strong dollar, a weakening world market, and unreliable surface water that keeps a lot of our land out of production.”KFSN-TV ABC 30 Frenso/Visalia (Calif.), Aug. 9, 2016
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Desal plant being built to provide drought-resistant water supply for communities in Monterey County, California
Description: A 250-feet deep test well was drilled on a remote beach in Marina as part of a plan to construct a $320 million desalination plant to provide water for 100,000 citizens in Monterey, Carmel and other nearby communities by 2019.  Numerous other desal plants were under construction along the coast as California endured historic drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 10, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Monterey County, CA, Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA, Marina, CA, Monterey, CA

Title: Californians with respiratory illnesses experiencing more problems on account of drought, other factors
Description: Californians with respiratory illnesses were experiencing more problems on account of the drought, with more fallow fields, more forest fires, stagnant air and other matters sending particles into the air.  Particle pollution has risen in 25 counties in the state, including Sacramento, where the count of unhealthy particle days has almost tripled since 2014, as reported in the American Lung Association’s State of the Air report, issued in April.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 28, 2015

Title: Most California water rights holders did not respond to the State Water Resources Control Board’s curtailment orders
Description: Most California water rights holders ordered to curtail pumping did not respond to the State Water Resources Control Board’s seven day deadline for confirmation of compliance.  Just 2,814 of the 9,112 curtailment orders issued to junior and senior water rights holders in 2015 acknowledged the confirmation orders.  Those who ignore the curtailment order could face fines of up to $1,000 daily and $2,500 per acre-foot of illegally diverted water.  Officials were unsure why the response was so poor.In addition, some senior water rights holders were challenging the curtailment order in court, asserting that the rights were curtailed without due process, or proper authority.  Los Angeles Times, June 22, 2015

Title: Populations of breeding waterfowl fall in California
Description: The populations of breeding waterfowl in the Sacramento Valley declined 19 percent this year, while decreases of such birds were larger elsewhere in California, on account of drought and poor habitat conditions, revealed a study by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife.  The survey was performed over prime nesting areas in the Central Valley and northeastern California and estimated 315,580 breeding ducks in 2015, a decline of nearly 30 percent from the 448,750 breeding ducks in 2014.  The largest population drops were noted in the northeast, where decreases of 40 percent occurred, stated a biologist with the CDFW.  There were 27 percent fewer breeding mallards, the most common duck species in the state.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 29, 2015

Title: Southern Central Valley farmworkers struggling to survive without work
Description: Farmworkers in the southern Central Valley continued to struggle to get by as agricultural employers cut jobs, due to drought, leading to hunger in an area where half of the country’s fruits, vegetables and nuts are grown. Many laborers relied on charity to keep food on the table. Undocumented workers suffer most because they cannot get food stamps and other federal assistance. The ripple effects are felt by farm-related businesses as the regional economy shares the pain.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 26, 2014

Title: Bears making trouble in Lake Tahoe area
Description: Bears in the Reno-Tahoe area caused more havoc than usual as drought drastically reduced their normal food and water resources, driving them to seek food in human-inhabited areas. In addition to diving into garbage, one bear sought entry to a bakery, and another crashed a hotel hors d’oeuvres table. During 2014, the Nevada Department of Wildlife caught and released 93 bears, an increase of 130 percent compared to 2009 and a 34 percent increase from ten years ago. In 2013, 97 bears were caught and released. The year of record bear activity was 2007 when 159 bears were captured amid drought.Las Vegas Sun, Dec. 24, 2014

Title: Bird species in the Sonoran Desert were delaying nesting
Description: Thirteen bird species in the Sonoran Desert were delaying nesting by two or more weeks in response to drought conditions and by several weeks during episodes of intense drought.  These delays can jeopardize reproduction or leave birds in poor condition and unable to recover before the next breeding season.Science World Report (New York), Dec. 23, 2014

Title: High prices at Palo Alto, California farmers market mirrors high production costs for farmers
Description: Some farms in San Luis Obispo County have closed during the drought to minimize losses until substantial rain returns.  Farmers with springs and wells are pumping heavily, more quickly than the source can be replenished.  A ranch owner in Cayucos said his costs have tripled and will not likely break even this year.  A dairy farmer reported that her expense for hay and alfalfa feed had risen 2½ times from 2011 to this year.  With feed costs rising from $20,000 to $50,000, she had to give up her organic certification and may have to quit the business.  A profit this year is an impossibility.Demand for imported hay and alfalfa is high, as are costs, further keeping profits down.  Hay production in 2014 was 6 million tons, in comparison with the 8 million tons grown in 2002. Similarly, prices at the Palo Alto farmers market have skyrocketed.  A half-gallon of raw milk goes for about $8, one dozen eggs sells for $10, and a pound of rib steak runs about $27 per pound.  In spite of the high prices, farmers’ expenses still are not covered.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Dec. 21, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Palo Alto, CA

Title: Lack of snow in Sierra Nevada in California drove skiers to travel to ski areas in Washington, Idaho
Description: Thin snowpack in the Sierra Nevada has driven downhill and Nordic skiers to snowier areas, such as Sun Valley in Idaho and Methow Valley in north central Washington, for good skiing until the California mountains get more snow.  Precipitation in California has come down as rain rather than snow or has stayed at high elevations, leaving ski resorts bare.Twin Falls Times-News (Idaho), Feb. 9, 2015

Title: Residents not always appreciative of water conservation in Coachella Valley, California
Description: Golf courses in the Coachella Valley were asked by the Coachella Valley Water District to curb water use by 10 percent between 2010 and 2020.  People who live around the golf courses and pay high membership dues and initiation fees expect the grass to be lush and green, drought or not.  The area draws from a large aquifer and does not have the same water concerns that many others in the state have.  In addition, water agencies may not charge more than it costs to treat the water, so water rates remain low--$1.12 for 748 gallons, which does not encourage conservation.Los Angeles Times, Dec. 20, 2014

Title: Metropolitan Water District in Southern California to sell water to Water Replenishment District
Description: Abundant rainfall in December increased the water allocation to the Metropolitan Water District, making it able to sell 25,000 acre-feet of water to the Water Replenishment District for the first time in three years.  The water will be used to refill underground aquifers in Southeast Los Angeles County and will be transferred from January through April 2015.Drought and other factors have prevented MWD from selling water to replenish underground aquifers.San Gabriel Valley Tribune (Calif.), Dec. 20, 2014

Title: East Bay Municipal Utility District in California considering purchase of federal water from Sacramento River
Description: The rate hike for East Bay has been suspended until the East Bay Municipal Utility District decides whether to pump Sacramento River water. The start of the pumping and the surcharge could begin on Jan. 19 if the district chooses to move ahead with the plan.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 6, 2015Despite the recent storms, the East Bay Municipal Utility District will raise water rates 14 percent for the next few months to pay for extra federal water.  The EBMUD board voted to buy water from the Sacramento River and request a further reduction in water use from 10 percent to 15 percent.  If the region gets heavy storms in the next few weeks, the water purchase and uptick in water rates may not happen.San Leandro Times (Calif.), Dec. 18, 2014

Title: Possible rate hike in Alameda County Water District in California
Description: The Alameda County Water District’s board of directors was considering the possibility of another rate hike in 2015 for the 13th straight year.  Drought has pushed up expenses which the agency passes on to customers.  The general manager for the ACWD said the goal was to increase revenue by 8 percent.  Unfortunately as customers use less water, the agency takes in less revenue and must increase water rates.A drought surcharge which took effect in July remained in effect.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Council members in Santa Barbara, California considering new restrictions, preparing for continuing drought
Description: Santa Barbara council members considered more water-use and development restrictions as drought persisted despite recent rainfall.  All seemed to be in favor of the possibility of suspending approvals of new private groundwater well permits and of water restrictions on turf, but disagreed about whether to prohibit installing new pools and issuing  building permits for projects with net new water use.To prepare for a continuation of the drought, city groundwater well replacements took on new urgency, as did preparations to reactivate the city’s desalination facility. Noozhawk (Santa Barbara, Calif.), Dec. 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Consideration of moratorium on new wells, groundwater exports in Merced County, California
Description: A moratorium on new wells and groundwater export was under consideration by the Merced County board of supervisors as the past few years of drought raise concern about having a sufficient supply of water.  The moratorium was voted down at the Dec. 16 meeting, but will be revisited in 2015. KFSN-TV ABC 30 Frenso/Visalia (Calif.), Dec. 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Merced County, CA

Title: Report recommended less groundwater pumping near coast, more pumping from inland sources in Salinas Valley, California
Description: A Salinas Valley groundwater basin report recommended that pumping be shifted away from the coast to deeper underground water sources to reduce seawater intrusion worsened by drought.  Agricultural interest groups opposed the recommendation.  While seawater intrusion changed little during 2011-13, it seems to have penetrated further inland in 2014.  The report was researched and prepared by Brown and Caldwell, a firm based in Sunnyvale.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 17, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Monterey County, CA, San Benito County, CA

Title: Rain barrels, rain collection systems increasingly popular in East Bay, California
Description: Rain barrels and large scale rain collecting systems have become increasingly popular in East Bay as a three year drought hangs on despite recent storms.  A Los Gatos man constructed a network of pipes, tanks and filters to capture rainwater and has collected more than 10,000 gallons.  A rainwater and greywater collection business saw an uptick in sales of 30 percent as people invest in collection system equipment, design and consultation.  Several large systems capable of holding 20,000 to 40,000 gallons were in the works.  Because large systems can cost up to $70,000, many people opt for small cisterns.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 16, 2014

Title: Suspenstion of higher water rates in East Bay, California
Description: The rate hike has been suspended until the East Bay Municipal Utility District decides whether to pump Sacramento River water.  The start of the pumping and the surcharge could begin on Jan. 19 if the district chooses to move ahead with the plan.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 6, 2015The East Bay Municipal Utility District board voted unanimously to supplement its Sierra reservoirs with water purchased from the Central Valley Water Project and to raise rates for customers, if needed.  If district managers determine this month that additional water is needed, a 14 percent surcharge will be added to bills possibly for six months or so until the cost of the extra water has been paid .  The district may purchase 16,000 acre-feet of water and maybe up to 35,000 acre-feet from the Central Valley Water Project if deliveries are limited due to drought.  The price tag for the water would be $16 million.The district board voted to raise voluntary water conservation from 10 percent to 15 percent beginning Jan. 1.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Dec. 9, 2014
