Title: Continued state of emergency in Humboldt County, California; request for water to prevent fish kill
Description: The Humboldt County Board of Supervisors extended the local state of emergency and sent a letter to the Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell, asking her to release water from Trinity Lake to avert fish kills stemming from low flows and warm water in the Trinity and Klamath rivers.  The flow of the Klamath River as measured by the U.S. Geological Survey was less than the minimum 2,500 cubic feet per second to provide safe conditions and lower than the nearly 2,000 cubic feet per second during which the massive 2002 fish kill occurred.The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation said on July 31 that no additional water would be released to the Trinity and Klamath rivers, but water would be directed to the Sacramento River for the protection of federally endangered chinook salmon.  The Humboldt County Board of Supervisors extended the local state of emergency through Sept. 9 as drought continued.  The additional time allows local tribes and municipalities another 28 days to seek emergency assistance from the state.Willits News (Calif.), Aug. 13, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced $779,200 for emergency projects in Santa Barbara County, California and Socorro County, New Mexico
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced that it will provide $779,200 for emergency projects in Santa Barbara County, California and Socorro County, New Mexico.  In California, the Cachuma Operation and Maintenance Board will get $300,000 to pump water from Lake Cachuma into the North Portal Intake Structure to maintain water supplies to the south coast municipalities in Santa Barbara County.  Water is anticipated to drop below the intake structure in Lake Cachuma this fall.The Alamo Band of the Navajo Nation Chapter Well in New Mexico will receive $479,000 to drill a new well to bolster its water supplies. Title: Happy Camp Fire consumed 132,000 acres in Klamath National Forest in Northern California
Description: The Happy Camp Fire has been the costliest fire in California in 2014 at $86 million.  The King Fire comes in second place at more than $53 million.  USA Today, Sept. 25, 2014Through Sept. 25, the Happy Camp Complex consumed at least 132,733 acres since the blaze began on Aug. 11. Title: Water theft by Northern California marijuana growers has drawn increasing attention from law enforcement
Description: Water theft by marijuana growers has drawn increasing attention from law enforcement in Lake, Mendocino and Humboldt counties as drought depletes water supplies.  Marijuana growers often illegally divert water, dam creeks and siphon water from springs on others’ property.Lake County officials approved an ordinance that requires growers to account for their water supply.  Both Lake and Mendocino counties have a tip line for the public to anonymously report illegal water use.Bend Bulletin (Ore.), Aug. 7, 2014

Title: Drought and water crisis in California has brewery owners seeking out practical ways to curb water use
Description: The drought and water crisis in California has brewery owners seeking out practical ways to curb water use as the lack of precipitation dries up water supplies.  The lack of water is a disproportionate threat to small brewers because they have less efficient equipment and use about twice as much water as large traditional breweries to make a barrel of beer, according to an industry spokesman.  The Bear Republic brewery, for example, gets its water from the Russian River, but regulations in its water district have capped the breweries’ water use at 8 million gallons of water annually, according to the master brewer.  The brewery was installing a waste water-filtration system and partially funded the construction of two wells.  Business plans envisioned growth of 35 percent this year, but circumstances have only permitted 15 percent growth.  Everett Herald (Wash.), Aug. 7, 2014

Title: Drought emergency in San Bernardino County, California
Description: San Bernardino County supervisors made a drought emergency proclamation on Aug. 5, 2014, and the proclamation has been extended monthly since then.  Drought conditions since 2012 and extremely low snowpack in California’s mountains spurred county supervisors to take action.As of Dec. 15, the California Department of Water Resources reported that snowpack in the north, central and southern sections of the Sierra Nevada mountains amounted to 36, 40 and 56 percent, respectively, of normal levels.  The county's emergency services manager warned that drought affects health, safety and economic conditions, and may lead to catastrophic wildfires.Lake Arrowhead Mountain News (Calif.), Dec. 17, 2014

Description: Lightning sparked numerous fires in Northern California, forcing residents from their homes as firefighters tried to hold back the flames.  The Eiler Fire charred 25,900 acres, eight homes, a restaurant and an old post office near Burney in Shasta County. Besides chasing dozens of residents from 40 homes, the blaze  stopped trains on a nearby track.  The Day Fire on the Shasta-Modoc County line consumed 12,975 acres and five homes.The El Portal Fire on the western edge of Yosemite National Park blackened 4,689 acres after burning two homes in Foresta and was nearly fully contained.The French Fire in the southern Sierra between Bass Lake and Huntington Lake burned 13,267 acres and was 30 percent contained. Title: State of emergency in California
Description: The governor of California issued an emergency proclamation of a state of emergency on Aug. 2 as wildfires blazed in El Dorado, Amador, Butte, Humboldt, Lassen, Madera, Mariposa, Mendocino, Modoc, Shasta and Siskiyou counties. Title: Well drillers in the Central Valley of California working overtime to meet demand
Description: Well drillers in the Central Valley are working overtime to meet demand as farmers do all that they can to find water.  The vice president of Arthur & Orum Well Drilling Inc. in Fresno said that his company drilled 22 wells in June, twice as many as usual and have a backlog of 12 to 13 months.  The company gets seven to 10 calls daily from desperate farmers needing water, so his crews work 24 hours a day trying to accomplish as much as they can.One farmer waited one year and spent $500,000 to have a well drilled.  He did not want to pay the high cost of drilling the well, but it seemed to be the best way to get water.Some farmers were paying up to 10 times what they used to for water.Washington Post, Aug. 1, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality

Title: About a third of the irrigators in the Klamath Basin of Oregon and California out of water
Description: About a third of the irrigators in the Klamath Basin of Oregon and California received notice from the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation that water was at an end this year.  Letters from Reclamation said that inflows to the Klamath Reclamation Project’s primary reservoir were below pre-season forecasts from the Natural Resources Conservation Service, resulting in a reduction in water releases to districts with junior water rights so that minimum levels for endangered fish could be met.  Fifty thousand acres of land will not receive any more water this year.  Since most of those farms grow hay, those farmers may lose up to half of their crop for the year, said Greg Addington of the Klamath Water Users Association.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 5, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Drought reducing habitat, water supplies along Pacific Flyway
Description: This year is expected to be a very difficult one for North American waterfowl that travel along the Pacific Flyway.  With the drought, there are fewer remaining water sources in the Central Valley, meaning birds will be crowded into smaller areas, making it easier to transmit diseases and more challenging to find enough food.  In a typical year, about 5 million waterfowl winter on state and federal wildlife refuges and flooded rice fields in the Central Valley.  Water supplies to wildlife refuges in the Central Valley were reduced by 25 percent.  Rice acreage was cut by a similar amount as farmers received less irrigation water.  Breeding season in Canada has been very successful, leading to a large number of birds heading to the Central Valley soon, said the Western region director of Ducks Unlimited.  He expects disease and a food shortage, due to dried up rice fields and withered wetlands.The California Department of Fish and Wildlife asked the public to observe waterfowl and report sick birds with the hope of stemming an avian botulism outbreak if caught in the early stages. Disease already killed at least 1,700 dead waterfowl, mostly mallard ducks, at Tule Lake, part of the Klamath National Wildlife Refuge on the Oregon-California border.  Ten to 20 dead ducks were found in a canal in the Pocket neighborhood of Sacramento, near Portuguese Community Park.  Roughly the same number of birds died in a city pond in Hesperia in San Bernardino County.  Avian botulism is likely the culprit in all cases, but lab tests have not yet verified the presence of the pathogen.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 30, 2014

Title: Drought led Truckee Meadows Water Authority to turn to reserves
Description: Customers of the Truckee Meadows Water Authority cut water use by 7.5 percent, despite a request for 10 percent water conservation.  Despite the small shortfall, the water savings allowed the TMWA to avoid drawing water from its largest drought reserve reservoir, Independence Lake, and to keep the use of its drought reserves to 18 percent, with the goal being less than 20 percent of the 27,500 acre-feet available.Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Nov. 6, 2014The Truckee Meadows Water Authority asked its water customers to lower their water use by 10 percent, as drought sapped water supplies.  The flow from Boca Reservoir into the Truckee River ended in late July. As the summer wore on, the TMWA relied on water from the Stampede Reservoir and then Donner Lake, after Labor Day, to bolster the flow in the river.  Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Sept. 26, 2014

Title: Santa Clara Valley Water District in California considers prioritizing native fish over outdoor water uses
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District Board’s Environmental and Water Resources Committee urged the board in July 2014 to prioritize fishes’ survival over non-essential human uses, such as washing cars and watering lawns.In January 2015, Santa Clara County officials were debating whether to withhold water from people during drought to sustain fish, such as steelhead trout and Chinook salmon, and were seeking opinions from their water customers before deciding.  Water levels and fish populations dropped immensely this year.Invasive fish populations, which favor warm, stagnant water, thrive during drought when native fish are suffering without cool flowing water.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Jan. 6, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Water users in Merced County, California cooperating to prevent additional land subsidence
Description: Excessive groundwater pumping and resulting land subsidence has two Merced County men, a farmer and the general manager of  San Luis Canal Co., working together, recruiting area farmers to create solutions that prevent additional subsidence but  meet water needs.  Shifting soils have caused area wells to collapse, and three feet of subsidence in the last five years will force the San Luis Canal Co. to rebuild part of Sack Dam if it is to hold water rather than spill it.  Some mitigative efforts could include absorbing more rainwater in fallow fields for storage underground, storing floodwater, using highly efficient irrigation methods, lobbying for new reservoirs and possibly regulating California groundwater.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Merced County, CA, Los Banos, CA

Title: El Portal fire charred 2,600 acres near Yosemite National Park in California
Description: The El Portal Fire on the western edge of Yosemite National Park has blackened 4,689 acres after burning two homes in Foresta and was nearly fully contained.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 4, 2014The El Portal fire charred 2,600 acres of thick, dry vegetation on steep hillsides on the western side of Yosemite National Park near El Portal, California since the fire began on July 26.  Residents were evacuated from the communities of El Portal and Foresta and three campsites, Crane Flat, Yosemite Creek and Bridalveil Creek.  A duplex in Foresta was destroyed by the blaze.  The El Portal fire was burning south of the area affected by the Rim Fire, which consumed more than 250,000 acres in and adjacent to Yosemite in 2013.Fresno Bee (Calif.), July 28, 2014
Places: Mariposa County, CA, El Portal, CA

Title: Salmon dying in warm, low river flows in Humboldt County, California
Description: Fifty-five adult salmon and an unusually high number of juvenile salmon were found dead along a 90-mile stretch of the Salmon River in Northern California’s Klamath Basin, according to an environmental scientist for the California Department of Fish and Wildlife.  Low water flows and high temperatures are expected to kill more fish.  Given the drought, there is little to no available water to improve conditions for the fish.  A massive fish kill occurred in the same area in 2002.Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), July 25, 2014
Places: Humboldt County, CA

Title: Insufficient grass growth for livestock in San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: Grasses on the Hearst Ranch in San Simeon were just ankle-high when they would normally be 18 inches high as drought stunted grass growth.  Ranch managers would like to expand the cattle herd of 900 head by another 100 head per year, but drought has put the brakes on the plan because the cost of supplemental feed meeting the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s standards for keeping the grass-fed beef label is too high.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 25, 2014
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Sand Fire scorched 3,800 acres in Amador, El Dorado counties in California
Description: The Sand Fire scorched 3,800 acres of thick grasses and forest in steep river canyons in Amador and El Dorado counties.  The wind-driven blaze also destroyed 13 homes and 38 outbuildings east of Sacramento since the fire began on July 25, when it is thought that a car inadvertently sparked a fire in tall grass.The fire was 75 percent contained on the afternoon of July 28, which will soon allow firefighters to permit the residents of 1,900 homes to return after being evacuated.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 29, 2014
Places: Amador County, CA, El Dorado County, CA

Title: Spray parks in Bakersfield, California to closed, stage 3 water restrictions began
Description: Bakersfield’s Water Board was considering reopening the city’s nine water parks on a shortened schedule since state water regulators lifted mandatory water conservation targets.  The entire city council will hear the report and vote on a new conservation standard on June 8.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), May 25, 2016Nine spray parks in Bakersfield will close on Aug. 1 when the state’s mandatory water conservation measures take effect.  The spray parks would normally be open into September for kids to cool off during the hot late summer days.  To make up for the loss of the spray parks, the recreation and parks director said that free or discounted entry into city pools and the McMurtrey Aquatic Center would be offered.All spray parks in Kern County would also likely close if Bakersfield goes ahead and closes its spray parks on Aug. 1, said the director of parks and recreation.Bakersfield will also move to stage 3 drought condition, bringing mandatory water restrictions, as the state mandated.  The city attorney said that the city intends to take an educational approach to the new water restrictions and will not immediately begin fining residents for water violations.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), July 23, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA, Bakersfield, CA

Title: Agencies in Los Angeles County to curb water use
Description: Los Angeles County’s board of supervisors voted unanimously to order government agencies within the county to abide by the state water restrictions and use less water.  The board also asked the public works department to see what changes could be made to meet the new state rules.Los Angeles Times, July 22, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Level of Lake Tahoe falling, allowing more damage to boat propellers
Description: The dropping level of Lake Tahoe has exposed obstacles that are nearer to the water’s surface and are damaging propellers, said the general manager of the Tahoe City Marina.  The lake has become too shallow for some sailboats to come into the marina.  Sand Harbor’s boat ramp on Tahoe’s East Shore closed for the rest of the season on July 28, according to Nevada Division of State Parks.  The parking lot will stay open for boats that can be carried to the water, but all other watercraft must go to the Cave Rock boat ramp.  Tahoe Daily Tribune (Nev.), July 22, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Drought surcharge adopted in Alameda County, California to fill budget gap of $15 million
Description: The Alameda County Water District approved a drought surcharge on July 17, and the new water rates took effect July 21.  The surcharge was needed to fill a budget gap of $15 million, which agency leaders attribute to the drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), July 21, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA

Title: Some California cities considering hiring water police
Description: Some California cities are considering hiring water police to look into complaints about water use violations, write tickets and issue fines.  The Santa Clara Valley Water District board met on July 22 to decide whether to hire as many as 10 temporary employees to enforce water restrictions.  The proposal is expected to be approved.  Santa Cruz and Sacramento are two cities that fine scofflaws, but water authorities in most cities prefer to avoid penalizing customers.The East Bay Municipal Utility District in Oakland hired an outreach person with another starting next week.  The district already has nine other staff members who provide free water audits, look for leaks and educate home and business owners about district and state water regulations.The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission intends to hire or reassign six employees to look into reports of water waste.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), July 21, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Sacramento, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Francisco, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz, CA

Title: Early grape harvest in California
Description: Drought and heat pushed grapes to ripen early this year, posing a problem for UC Davis’ winemaking institute.  Classes do not begin for another five weeks, so the grape juice will sit longer than usual before the students can begin to make wine with it.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 21, 2014The mild, dry winter led to an early bud break in California and an early grape harvest.  Harvesting usually begins in early to mid-August, but South Coast Winery, Resort & Spa in Temecula began picking grapes during the week of July 14, and the harvest began at Bailey Vineyard & Winery, also in Temecula, on July 22.  A vineyard manager near Temecula said, "I think part of (the early harvest) has to do with the drought and the mild winter we just had.  Plus we had a really mild spring and summer so far. This is about the earliest start I can remember.”Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), July 22, 2014

Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced $9.7 million in additional drought relief for rural Californians in 11 counties to help with dry wells and other water sources. Title: California almond production forecast higher
Description: Despite dire predictions for the almond crop in California this year, growers have managed to secure enough water to keep their trees alive and thriving, resulting in a 4.5 percent increase in almond production, rather than the production drop of 2.5 percent forecast in May.Expectations for a small crop drove prices higher, with almonds selling for more than $3 per pound, topping the previous record high of $2.81 in 2006.Washington Post (D.C.), July 17, 2014

Title: Many problems with wells in Butte County, California
Description: Domestic wells have continued to run dry in Butte County, but county officials do not know how many people were having problems with their wells.  Because it is expensive to have water trucked to homes, county officials would like to offer more sites where water can be purchased.  Potable water is available for purchase in Oroville from South Feather Water and Power Agency and from Durham Mutual Water Company. The general manager of South Feather said that about two-thirds of the 100 loads of water purchased in May were for construction.  In June, just one-third of the roughly 100 loads of water purchased were for construction, suggesting that the difference might be for residential delivery.The Butte County emergency service officer estimated that there were about 60 properties with dry wells, including Forest Ranch, Cohasset, Butte Valley, Mesilla Valley, Bangor and Durham.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), July 19, 2015Water levels in Butte County have dropped, keeping well drillers busy.  The owner of a pump repair business said that he has been getting a dozen calls per day about wells with many of those near irrigated orchards, presumably where water demand is higher.  In his experience, groundwater was low near Durham, Orland and Capay, and in some places, the water level has fallen 10 feet and not come back up.  He worries that if the drought continues and water levels continue to fall, that it will adversely affect his business when there is no longer water to pump.A well driller in Chico has been busy working on wells on Garner Lane, Kathy Lane and Stable Lane where the depth of the wells ranged from 65 to 80 feet deep.  In the Cohasset and Forest Ranch areas, there is trouble with wells, particularly those more than 15 years old.  In parts of Cohasset, the water is 700 to 800 feet below ground.  The well driller noted that the entire town of Nord must drill deeper to reach water at a cost of roughly $8,000 per well.  Wells were also running dry near Chico River Road, Henshaw Avenue, Pleasant Valley High School and Five Mile Recreation Area.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), July 17, 2014
Places: Butte County, CA, Bangor, CA, Chico, CA, Cohasset, CA, Durham, CA, Forest Ranch, CA, Nord, CA, Orland, CA

Title: Campfires banned below 6,000 feet in Yosemite National Park in California
Description: Campfires were banned in Yosemite National Park below 6,000 feet, due to the ongoing intense drought and increased fire danger.  People may still build campfires in picnic areas and designated campgrounds.  Los Angeles Times, July 16, 2014
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Rafting coming to an early close on the Truckee River in California
Description: The Truckee River Rafting Company closed on July 16 and 17 until a heavy storm brought enough rain to increase the flow of the river.  The owner of the rafting company was not sure whether the business would still be open at the end of the week, due to the low flow in the river.  He expected to be closed in August, which would cost the rafting company nearly all of its profit for the year.  Rafting usually continues through August in a normal year.The IRIE Rafting Company scheduled trips on the Truckee River through Aug. 1, but cannot offer trips beyond that date because the water master will not be releasing enough water for rafting trips.  The rafting season normally extends into October in a normal year.Tahoe Daily Tribune (Calif.), July 22, 2014

Title: Residents with well problems urged to make report in Butte County, California
Description: The Butte County Department of Water and Resource Conservation sent out a notice requesting that residents with dry or sputtering wells, low water pressure or sand in their water file a voluntary online report.  About a dozen reports have been submitted.  The county’s water scientist said that the reports have come from the Durham Dayton Road, near Vina, along Stanford Avenue in Durham and in the foothills and that many of the wells were about 60 to 70 feet deep.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), July 17, 2014

Title: Gravenstein apple crop small, early in Sonoma County, California
Description: The crop of Gravenstein apples was light this year and was ready for harvest in mid-July, which was earlier than usual, stated a third-generation apple grower.  The heirloom apples grow particularly well in Sonoma County. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 5, 2014
Places: Watsonville, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Sebastopol, CA

Title: Low groundwater levels and drought were intensifying water problems in the San Joaquin Valley, California
Description: Low groundwater levels and drought were intensifying water problems in the San Joaquin Valley, causing wells to run dry and leaving communities in a very tight spot when a well breaks down.  In Stratford in Kings County, the water table around the community’s well fell 100 feet during the last two years, according to data uncovered by Fresno Bee reporter Lewis Griswold.  Excessive groundwater pumping was responsible for the land subsidence in the region, amounting to a drop of nearly 30 feet between 1925 and 1977 and another 10 feet since 1977, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.  With the water table falling, it becomes more expensive and difficult to reach down deeper for water.Fresno Bee (Calif.), July 14, 2014
Places: Kings County, CA

Title: Hungry bears causing problems near Lake Tahoe, California
Description: “Drought” bears are causing trouble in the Lake Tahoe area as they move into residential areas, feasting on garbage and even nosing around people’s belongings on the beach at Lake Tahoe.  Wildlife biologists expected that ongoing drought would lead to more trouble with bears in the Sierra Nevada as three years of drought have nearly dried up mountain streams and limited the amount of natural foods for bears, said the chief wildlife biologist for the Nevada Department of Wildlife.Wildlife officials nabbed their seventh problem bears in the last 10 days at Tahoe.  Another bear was struck and killed by a car last week.  Many bears can be trapped and relocated, but if they become too bold and lose their fear of humans, they must be euthanized.  Elko Daily Free Press (Nev.), July 13, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Onyx, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Generous water sale from west San Joaquin Valley water holders to east-side farmers in California
Description: Although California water has been selling for exceptionally high prices of more than $2,000 per acre-foot, west Valley farmers with senior water rights to the San Joaquin River have water to sell to east-side districts in the Friant Water Authority, including Terra Bella, Lindmore, Kern Tulare, Stone Corral and Orange Cove.  East side farmers received an allocation of zero percent.  The 13,500 acre-feet of water sold for a mere $250 per acre-foot, in contrast to other water sales of late that commanded more than $2,000 per acre-foot.This was a very generous water deal, which could have made the sellers $27 million, rather than $3.375 million.Fresno Bee (Calif.), July 12, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Wildfire in Shasta County, California near marijuana farm burned 3,700 acres
Description: A wildfire in Shasta County burned 3,700 acres and was just 10 percent contained.  It began when a hot vehicle ignited dry grass.  The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection said that 1,056 firefighters were attacking the blaze.  USA Today, July 14, 2014
Places: Shasta County, CA

Title: Years of drought have hampered recreational activities in California
Description: Years of drought have hampered recreational activities in California as rivers and lakes become increasingly depleted, and conditions are expected to deteriorate as summer progresses.  In San Mateo County, a camp ground in Memorial County Park was closed, due to the lack of water and the presence of algae.  Water was too low for kayaking and canoeing at Stevens Creek and Lexington reservoirs in Santa Clara County.  Fishing was temporarily forbidden in many coastal streams to protect the salmon and steelhead struggling to navigate the shallow waters.   A swim lagoon at Castaic Lake in Santa Clarita closed, due to low water.  Porta potties were in use at the Hearst Castle visitor center to conserve water.  Visitors to the Mt. Diablo State Park must bring along their own water because springs were running slowly.  Six of the nine boat ramps at Folsom Lake were closed, due to low water levels.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), July 12, 2014
Places: California, Livermore, CA, Kern County, CA, Santa Clarita, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Effort to keep Los Gatos Creek flowing into downtown San Jose, California
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District has opted to reduce flows from Lexington and Vasona reservoirs to extend the length of time that water can be released from the reservoirs to keep Los Gatos Creek from going dry.  Normal flow from Lexington Reservoir is 12 cubic feet per second, but it was reduced to 5 cubic feet per second, which will keep the creek flowing to the Guadalupe River in downtown San Jose.   Without limiting the flow from the reservoir, the creek would probably be dry by October, said the district.  The creek is home to numerous native fish species, such as steelhead and rainbow trout, California roach, Sacramento sucker and prickly and riffle sculpin, and also several non-native fish species, like largemouth bass, common carp and bluegill.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), July 9, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Water conservation fell short of goal in Santa Clara County, California
Description: Water consumption in Santa Clara County fell by an estimated 13 percent, a little short of the district’s goal of 20 percent.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), July 9, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Emergency funding for water system in Seville, California
Description: The water supply in Seville was deteriorating due to drought reducing the amount of water available and adversely affecting the quality of the remaining water.  People were relying heavily on groundwater, causing the water table to fall, and were told to boil their water in recent weeks.  The water crisis has made the town of 500 people eligible for emergency state funding and temporary fixes.  Deliveries of bottled water began on July 10. Fresno Bee (Calif.), July 9, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA

Title: More funds set aside for water conservation programs in Coachella Valley, California
Description: The Coachella Valley Water District in October 2014 added $1.8 million to its previous funding for water conservation programs for a total of $3.2 million since July 1.  More people had been applying for rebates through the turf removal program, which pays $1 per square foot of lawn removed up to a maximum of 1,000 square feet per project.  The water district has received up to 65 applications per week, said the agency's director of communication and conservation.  Between July 1 and late September, people sought rebates for the removal of nearly 2 million square feet of lawn to convert to drought-tolerant landscaping, totaling more square feet converted than in the first three years of the program.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Oct. 28, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Higher water rates in Napa, California
Description: The Napa City Council approved higher water rates to compensate for reduced water sales and revenue after years of drought.  Revenue from water sales dropped from $27 million in the 2013-14 fiscal year to $22.2 million in 2016-17, $6.7 million less than the city predicted as the state endured drought and water conservation mandates.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Nov. 8, 2017
Places: Napa County, CA, Napa, CA

Title: More funds for Metropolitan Water District's conservation programs, updates to water allocation plan
Description: The Metropolitan Water District announced the closing of the turf rebate program because the $350 million in funds has been spent in about one week since the money became available July 1, the start of the new fiscal year.  The district was receiving applications for projects amounting to about $12 million per week.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), July 8, 2015Metropolitan Water District officials voted to add $350 million to the fund used for turf removal rebates and water-saving efforts, bringing the total for the two-year incentive program to $450 million for fiscal years 2015-16.  The district had allotted $100 million to the fund previously, but the astounding response to the program, to which 2,500 to 3,000 turf removal applications are made weekly, amounts to payouts of $10 million per week.  Incoming requests were exceeding funding.Most of the applications were for residential projects, but commercial projects were larger and commanded bigger rebates.  On May 10, commercial rebates amounted to $38.7 million, while residential rebates reached $9.5 million. Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 26, 2015Metropolitan Water District will meet and discuss the possible addition of $150 million to its rebate program after handing out $100 million since the incentive was offered for the two fiscal years ending in 2016.  During the last week of April 2015, MWD received requests for more than $34 million in rebates, nearly three times the previous record for requests.  From July 2014 through April 2015, MWD handed out $77 million in reimbursements, including low-flow fixtures, rain barrels and weather-based irrigation controllers.“Every time there’s a statement by the governor or actions taken by the state water board, we see hikes” in interest in the rebate program, said the MWD spokesman.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 7, 2015The Metropolitan Water District’s board of directors supplemented its conservation budget by $40 million and updated its water allocation plan as the epic drought continued.  The increased funding for the rebate budget took it from $60 million to $100 million.  The public response to the rebate program has been phenomenal with more than $100 million in turf removal requests from July through November 2014.  In comparison, the district paid out $18.6 million for conservation programs between July 2013 and June 2014.The water allocation plan outlines the way imported water would be shared among 26 member agencies, including cities and water districts, during shortages and also lays out additional charges for excess use.  The board could implement its allocation plan in the first quarter of 2015 if drought persists, meaning member agencies would receive less water.Los Angeles Times, Dec. 9, 2014

Title: Fires burn around Lake Berryessa in California
Description: The Butts Canyon fire northwest of Lake Berryessa in Napa County began on July 1 and burned 4,300 acres of dry vegetation, two homes and seven outbuildings before it was 90 percent contained on the morning of July 7.On the other side of Lake Berryessa, the Monticello fire charred 6,488 acres since it began near the Monticello Dam on the evening of July 4.  The fire was 35 percent contained on the morning of July 7.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 7, 2014

Title: Residents of the San Francisco Bay area chafe when they see water being wasted
Description: Residents of the San Francisco Bay area chafe when they see water being wasted, especially the dutiful citizens who strive to conserve water.  Sprinklers watering pavement and car windshields, lush lawn surrounding a large vacant construction site, leaky pipes and thick green lawns are extravagances that some residents feel the region cannot afford during a years long drought.During August, the Santa Clara Valley Water District got nearly 240 reports of water waste, about four times more complaints than the district received earlier in the year.  The number of calls to the East Bay Municipal Utility District rose to 211 in July.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Sept. 2, 2014

Title: Drought, wastewater from oil pumping polluting aquifers in California's Central Valley; wells ordered to close
Description: Twelve oil and gas wells in the Central Valley were ordered to shut down to protect underground drinking water from being polluted.  Production was stopped voluntarily at 10 Kern County oil wells, and two others were given cease-and-desist orders, according to the head of oil, gas and geothermal resources for the California Department of Conservation.  Tests to detect contamination will be performed on groundwater near the wells, but, so far, no contamination has been detected.A review of more than 2,500 state authorizations of oil field injections uncovered the use of protected and potentially useful water aquifers to dispose of the wastewater.  The state determined that 176 of those were high priority concerns.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 3, 2015 and Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), March 3, 2015Aquifers in California’s Central Valley have long been repositories of wastewater from oil companies, and the wastewater has tainted the precious water that communities rely upon when surface water is scarce.  The wastewater contains a mix of briny water, hydrocarbons and trace chemicals and is put into aquifers holding poor quality water that nevertheless could be treated for drinking if needed.  The water contamination, coupled with drought, has limited available potable water.  The federal Environmental Protection Agency has warned the state that it will take control of the wells if a plan to protect aquifers from the wastewater dumping is not submitted by Feb. 6.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 2, 2015

Title: Groundwater levels dropping in California's South Bay area
Description: Groundwater levels in the Bay Area have dropped, forcing well owners to drill deeper at a hefty price to reach water again.  KNTV-TV NBC 11 Bay Area (San Jose, Calif.), June 24, 2014

Title: Drought slowing sudden oak death in California
Description: Drought has slowed the advance of sudden oak death, a disease which has killed thousands of mighty oak trees in California, by limiting the number of spores that spread the disease.  The rate of infection among California bay laurel trees tested in 17 western counties between Fort Bragg and San Luis Obispo ranged from 2 to 10 percent between April 4 and June 5.  In wetter years, the infection rate ranges from 20 to 80 percent.  "This is a little bit of a positive because it gives us an opportunity to see and attack the weakest link of the disease - that is, when the populations really, really shrink," stated Matteo Garbelotto, the forest pathologist heading the Forest Pathology and Mycology Laboratory at UC Berkeley. "The pathogen hates the drought. It's like an outbreak of influenza. When it is cold and wet, people get sick. We know that when it is dry, we do not have outbreaks."Some of the infected trees have been cut down and many more will be felled this summer.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 22, 2014

Title: Oak Fire near Copperopolis, California
Description: The Oak Fire charred 100 acres, destroyed an outbuilding and forced the evacuation of homes along Rita Way since the fire began on June 22.  A Cal Fire information officer stated that drought was a factor in the fire.  She said that rain last spring promoted grass growth, but was not plentiful enough to replenish trees and brush, which remained extremely dry.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 23, 2014

Title: Outingdale, California residents to use no more than 68 gallons daily
Description: The El Dorado Irrigation District told its Outingdale water customers to use no more than 68 gallons of water daily because the district has junior water rights in the Cosumnes River, which is the town’s only source of tap water.  The California Water Resources Control Board recently told junior water rights holders to stop their diversions.  An Outingdale couple told their daughter and three young grandchildren not to visit this summer because water supplies were too low.  Other residents have made changes to their daily routines to conserve water.Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 21, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The California Department of Fish and Wildlife moved rainbow trout from a hatchery on the American River
Description: The California Department of Fish and Wildlife moved rainbow trout from a hatchery on the American River and fingerling steelhead from a nearby hatchery because it was feared that water temperatures may be too high in a few weeks for the fish to survive.  The fish were being released months ahead of schedule and were smaller than they would normally be, which likely means that fewer fish will survive than usual.  In such situations, state officials would usually ask the federal Bureau of Reclamation to release some water from Folsom Lake, but the lake water was too warm to be of use.Altogether about 2 million fish, including 430,000 fingerling steelhead, were being rescued. Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 17, 2014
Places: Sacramento County, CA

Title: Campground closed in the Santa Cruz Mountains in San Mateo County, California
Description: All 154 tent sites in the Memorial County Park in Loma Mar were closed because Pescadero Creek was flowing too slowly to meet water demand for visitors.  The San Mateo County Park Department says the park will remain open in the daytime, but overnight camping will be suspended through June and probably for the rest of the summer as well.   Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 17, 2014 and San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Nov. 16, 2014
Places: San Mateo County, CA

Title: Drought in the Central Valley increased the number of people coming to FoodLink of Tulare County, California
Description: Drought in the Central Valley has increased the number of people coming to FoodLink of Tulare County to 22,000 individuals in May, 5,000 people more than usually come for assistance and 12 percent more than in May 2013.  The food bank director expected higher demand for food assistance in August, but did not foresee the greater need this spring.Salt Lake City Deseret Morning News (Utah), June 15, 2014
Places: Tulare County, CA

Title: Nonprofit group out of relief funds for several Central Valley counties in California
Description: Proteus Inc., a nonprofit group that works with farm workers and other low-income Central Valley denizens, has run out of funds for helping pay rent and utility bills.  Proteus received the drought relief funds in June from La Cooperativa Campesina de California (The Peasant Cooperative of California) through the California Department of Housing and Community Development.  The funds helped low-income families who were unemployed or underemployed due to drought in Tulare, Kings and Fresno counties.  About 1,890 families benefited from 3,470 services provided by Proteus through Oct. 30.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Nov. 4, 2014

Title: Drought exacerbates water problems in Central Valley of California
Description: The lack of rainfall has drawn more attention to the Central Valley’s water problems, where many wells and groundwater supplies are tainted with farm chemicals and are not suitable for drinking.  Drought has made the issue worse with higher concentrations of nitrates, arsenic and other chemicals and poor water quality as groundwater levels decline.  Many families pay for water that they will not drink and purchase bottled water for drinking, making their total monthly water bill very high.  Salt Lake City Deseret Morning News (Utah), June 15, 2014

Title: Dry wells, poor water production in Monson, California
Description: Domestic wells have been running dry and producing less water in Monson, a community of 40 homes and apartments, since June 2014. Title: Water rate increase partially to pay debt for East Bay Municipal Utility District in California
Description: The customers of the East Bay Municipal Utility District will begin paying 9.5 percent more for water on July 1 after the board voted unanimously in favor of the rate increase.  The second large increase in two years will help pay for deferred maintenance and allow the district to refinance and pay its $2 billion debt from projects, including its $460 million portion of a project to deliver Sacramento River water to the East Bay.  The river water allowed the district to avoid rationing water and charging drought rates this summer.  Voluntary water conservation is encouraged.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), June 10, 2014

Title: Crop production affected by low water supplies in Fallbrook, California
Description: Water supplies were dwindling in Fallbrook and affecting crop production, said a fruit grower.  Fewer mulberries grew, and the kumquats were blemished.Some farmers were allowing trees to die to direct the water to more lucrative tree species, such as almond and pistachio trees.  Experts said that higher produce prices would arrive at SoCal’s produce markets later when the usual harvests of tomatoes, melons, peppers and other crops  in the Central Valley do not happen. Milton McGiffen Jr. of UC Riverside, an expert on vegetable crops and drought, said produce currently being sold in farmers markets was coming from the Salinas and Imperial valleys.Business has been better than usual at the Long Beach farmers market because there was no rainy weather to keep people away.Orange County Register (Calif.), June 9, 2014

Title: Several California cities fell short of the 20 percent reduction in water use as ordered by the governor
Description: Several California cities have fallen short of the 20 percent reduction in water use that Gov. Jerry Brown called for months ago when he declared a drought emergency.  Water customers in San Francisco curbed their consumption by 8 percent, while water users in San Jose used more water in the first quarter of 2014, compared to last year.  East Bay Municipal Utility District customers used 3 percent less water between February and April, compared to the last three years.  While more than 75 percent of Californians surveyed by the Public Policy Institute view the shrinking water supplies as a problem and as many as 92 percent say they have made changes to conserve water, reductions in water use do not reflect intense concern.  In defense of the Bay Area, water experts say that the conservation ethic is strong and that people were already conserving water with water-efficient appliances and drought-tolerant plants, making it challenging to cut back further.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 9, 2014

Title: Fewer Asian vegetables grown in Central Valley of Califorina
Description: Much of the country’s Asian vegetables, such as long beans, Chinese eggplant, fuzzy gourd (mo qua) and other vegetables, are grown in the Central Valley of California.  The crops are produced on small to midsized farms, often ranging from one to 30 acres, by farmers who do not have the means to withstand challenges that drought brings, like dry wells.  Many Hmong and Mien farmers, who cultivate one to five-acre plots of land, cannot afford to install wells.  One farmer was permitted to put in a water line to a neighbor’s well after his own well went dry, but they charged him ten times what he used to pay for water.A merchant in San Francisco’s Wholesale Produce Market said that about half of the Central Valley farmers who used to grow Asian vegetables were no longer doing so because leasing land to Blue Diamond to grow almonds was a more stable source of income.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 6, 2014

Title: Water-sharing agreement in the Klamath Basin in southern Oregon keeps water flowing despite drought
Description: Parties in the Klamath Basin in southern Oregon, often at odds over water use, have compromised and come up with a water sharing deal that allows all parties to have some water.  The Klamath Tribes were awarded the most senior water rights in much of Upper Klamath Lake and portions of its tributaries, but they prefer to see cooperation among water users in the basin by balancing water distribution and supporting local economies.  Now water users are sharing the water shortage and are working together.  Without the agreement, irrigation would already have ended in the upper basin and Klamath Project, said Richard Whitman, Gov. John Kitzhaber’s natural resources policy director.Skeptics of the agreement say that it does not solve water shortage problems.Bend Bulletin (Ore.), June 6, 2014

Title: More people panning for gold as California's rivers dwindle
Description: More people were trying their hand at prospecting for gold in California’s rivers as drought drained them to trickles of their former selves and allowed access to sections of river that were previously too deep for prospecting.  Mining supply stores in Sacramento, Auburn and Bakersfield have seen an uptick in business as people pick up the needed supplies to strike it rich.  Even desert prospectors have grabbed their metal detectors to look for gold in areas that have been dry for years.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), June 5, 2014

Title: Complicated water deal to sustain thousands of acres of citrus trees in Tulare County, California
Description: Multiple water agencies cooperated to bring 5,400 acres of water at a cost of $1,200 per acre-foot—about six times the normal price of water—to save thousands of acres of citrus trees in the Terra Bella Irrigation District in Tulare County.  The high cost of the water will pay for returning the water to a Kern County water district in the future.  The general manager of the Terra Bella district said, “It's good news.  But it's still a tough time here because $1,200 per acre-foot of water is a lot of money."The Terra Bella Irrigation District will repay the Arvin-Edison Water Storage District in Kern County with five acres for every acre borrowed, or 25,000 acre-feet when rainfall returns to normal.  The cooperation of the San Joaquin River Exchange Contractors Authority, the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California and federal, state and other water agencies were needed to move the water in the Friant-Kern Canal to Terra Bella.  A total of 22 approvals was needed to make the swap happen.The cooperation among the water agencies is an achievement and shows a willingness to go out of their way to alleviate damage to agriculture during this intense drought.Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 5, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Fresno County, California, well went dry, almond trees dying

Title: Water rights holders making calls on water in the Klamath Basin in Oregon
Description: Oregon water masters were considering demands from Klamath Basin farmers and the Klamath Tribes in enforcing senior water rights as drought limits the availability of water, said a spokesperson for the Oregon Water Resources Department.  The city of Klamath Falls was ordered to shut down two municipal drinking water wells to leave more water for the Klamath Reclamation Project, serving 1,200 farmers along the Oregon-California border.  But Klamath Falls intends to fight the well closure order because state law holds human consumption needs at a higher priority than irrigation, according to the city manager.  The calls concerns water use on stretches of the Sprague, Wood and Sycan rivers and several creeks.Bend Bulletin (Ore.), June 13, 2014Irrigation districts and wildlife refuges in the Klamath Basin have made calls on water use, but the most senior water right holder, the Klamath Tribes, have not yet made a call.  Senior water rights holders have priority over junior water rights holders and will receive their full allotment before junior water right holders will.  The watermaster at the Klamath Falls office of the Oregon Water Resources Department does not yet know whether water use will be regulated this year.  Flows into Upper Klamath Lake and the snow pack at Crater Lake were far below average.  Irrigators were on edge, worried that water was going to be a concern in July.  The acting manager of the Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge said that the refuge has not received water deliveries since November and will likely be dry by the end of July.Walla Walla Union-Bulletin (Wash.), June 4, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Water-wasting activities banned in the East Bay Municipal Utility District in California
Description: The East Bay Municipal Utility District banned water-wasting activities, such as flooding gutters and watering lawns more than twice a week, and urged the public to push for greater water conservation.  EBMUD’s customers reduced their water use by 10 percent, but that was still short of the 20 percent water conservation sought by Gov. Brown.  Some of the other banned actions include using a hose without a shut-off valve to wash vehicles, using potable water to wash pavement or fill fountains that do not recirculate water, and watering landscaping more than twice weekly.Calls to the district to report water waste rose from 10 calls in June to 211 in July, said a spokeswoman for EBMUD.  The district added another two conservation specialists to its staff, bringing the total of staff handling complaints to 15.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 12, 2014

Title: Marijuana growers in Northern California’s coastal forests taking too much water from the area’s rivers and streams
Description: Marijuana growers in Northern California’s coastal forests were taking so much water from the area’s rivers and streams that they have virtually gone dry.  Drought, on top of heavy water use for the water-intensive crop, has made the problem more apparent.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), June 1, 2014

Title: Drought reducing number of organic dairy herds in the West
Description: Organic dairy herds in the West, particularly in the San Joaquin Valley, were shrinking because drought has driven farmers to sell their herds and quit the dairy business, according to the USDA’s Dairy Market News.  Net gains from a year of organic milking brought in less than selling the cattle for slaughter.  Some organic producers and representatives in the Northwest did not know of any new organic producers in the region who had gotten certification for starting a new organic dairy in the last several years.Dairy Herd Network (Lenexa, Kan.), May 31, 2014

Title: Late water delivery cost Fresno County, California orange grower his crop
Description: A Fresno County orange grower in the Terra Bella Irrigation District reported that emergency water did not arrive until May, which was too late to save his orange crop, which fell to the ground.  Some orange growers in the region fared slightly better, but have smaller oranges than normal.  Other orange growers have bulldozed the trees or simply let them die.  Managers of the Orange Cove-Sanger Citrus Association expect a smaller crop, but still hope to get a decent crop.  The board chairman of California Citrus Mutual noted that while the oranges may be on the small side now, there was still plenty of time for rainfall before the end of harvest in June.  California produces 85 percent of the country’s fresh citrus, with navel oranges being one of the state’s top crops, valued at more than $721 million annually.Ag Alert (Sacramento, Calif.), Nov. 12, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: The California Water Resources Board ordered 2,648 Sacramento Valley water agencies and users with junior water rights to stop withdrawing water from some rivers and streams
Description: Curtailments imposed by the State Water Resources Control Board have ended for junior water rights holders in the Sacramento and San Joaquin river watersheds dated after 1914 and the Russian River watershed.  Recent rainfall boosted river flow, allowing the board to lift curtailments, but dry weather could bring further curtailments.Curtailments remain in effect for the Scott River in far Northern California and Deer Creek in Tehama County.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Nov. 19, 2014The California Water Resources Board ordered 2,648 Sacramento Valley water agencies and users with junior water rights issued after 1914 to stop withdrawing water from the American, Feather and Yuba rivers and numerous streams.  Those affected are mainly farmers and large irrigation districts, but the city of Sacramento also must stop taking water from the Sacramento River because the city has junior water rights, although it has senior water rights for the American River.  Similar water cuts were last ordered in 1977.Members of the Colusa Drain Mutual Water Co. were warned to expect no water this year, leading growers to plant crops that could be watered using only alternate water sources, such as groundwater or other surface water supplies.  As a result, just 4,000 acres of the 20,000 acres usually planted with rice and irrigated by the Colusa Drain Mutual Water Co. were planted this year.  Drastic cuts in tomato and alfalfa planting also occurred in the district.The state Water board may handle the junior water rights holders in the San Joaquin Valley differently by asking water users to sign a voluntary water agreement, stating that they acknowledge the order and have stopped diverting water.  Senior water rights holders may be affected by curtailments in coming weeks as water supplies dwindle over the summer, but some senior water rights holders have already refused to allow reductions to their water rights and will make no allowances for wildlife and urban health and safety needs.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 29, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Nevada Irrigation District in California not making deliveries of fall irrigation water
Description: The Nevada Irrigation District has begun storing more water since the state water board ended its curtailment of diversions into storage.  The curtailment was in effect from May 27 through Nov. 12, 2014.Auburn Journal (Calif.), Dec. 17, 2014The Nevada Irrigation District will not deliver fall irrigation water because the district does not have enough storage and supply to do so and also because the State Water Resources Control Board curtailed thousands of water rights across the state earlier this year, leaving the district unsure of whether it has the legal right to divert and deliver water from Sierra Nevada streams.  Several thousand small agricultural customers in Nevada County and parts of Placer County usually receive fall water between Oct. 15 and Dec. 1.  It has been more than 20 years since the district was unable to provide water for fall irrigation.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Oct. 29, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA

Title: Hunters fire in Mariposa County, California burned more than 1,300 acres
Description: The Hunters fire in Mariposa County consumed more than 1,300 acres of dry brush, two homes and an outbuilding near Lake McClure since the fire began on May 26 near Hunters Valley Access Road in Bear Valley.  More than 670 firefighters were battling the blaze, which was 20 percent contained on the morning of May 28.  Steep terrain made the fire difficult to access.  "This fire is burning like it would in summer with the dry conditions we've been experiencing," said Cal Fire spokesman Daniel Berlant. Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 28, 2014
Places: Mariposa County, CA

Title: East side San Joaquin Valley growers filed lawsuit to stop water releases from Millerton Lake
Description: The Friant Water Authority, representing 15,000 growers on the east side of the San Joaquin Valley, filed a lawsuit to stop the release of water from Millerton Lake, saying that water from a Northern California water supply should be used to help west side growers, rather than junior water users, such as wildlife refuges and the State Water Project.  A long-established water-rights prioritization would have east side growers receiving the water in Millerton Lake.Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 22, 2014

Title: Greater water conservation urged in SoCal
Description: Officials with the Metropolitan Water District urged consumers to strive for greater water conservation in case the drought lasts into 2015.  The MWD boosted its Southland water reserves in the past two years and has been drawing heavily from Diamond Valley Lake and Castaic Lake in Los Angeles County.  Water deliveries from the State Water Project was to be 5 percent of normal, although the MWD usually gets about one-third of its annual supply from the SWP.  The MWD has taken a number of actions to help its customers understand the severity of the water situation.  The incentive for turf removal and other water conservation projects has been increased to reduce water use.  The MWD brought back the fuel gauge display to its website to help customers understand how much water the district has in reserve.  A new radio and television campaign was in the works for the summer, underscoring the importance of water conservation.  Two treatment plants that process Colorado River water were shut down to adapt their water delivery system to make drought-related changes.  Some maintenance projects were also deferred to keep the aqueduct system operation at nearly full capacity.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 22, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: California Water Resources Control Board may limit water use in tributaries of Sacramento River to maintain minimum flows for fish
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board approved regulations that could limit water use from low streams flowing into the Sacramento River this summer.  Farmers strongly opposed the new regulations, which set standards for the minimum volume of water that must flow in three Sacramento River watersheds when there are fish in them.  The standards allow state officials to limit water use when water levels are too low. Reuters (New York), May 21, 2014

Title: Kings River in Tulare County, California closed to motorized watercraft
Description: The Kings River in Tulare County was closed to motorized watercraft because there was too little water for boating, said the director of Parks and Recreation.  The river did not appear to be running and consisted of a series of pools.  All-terrain vehicles and motorcycles were prohibited in the riverbed.Boating was impossible in the Kings River in Fresno County, but there were no restrictions on boating, according to a law enforcement official.  The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers will begin releasing irrigation water from Pine Flat Dam in June, and there should be enough water in the river in July to support boating.Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 20, 2014

Title: Opposition to proposed sale of water from Merced County, California

A Merced County supervisor intends to seek the support of her colleagues for an emergency ordinance to prevent the sale.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 20, 2014

Title: Shortage of water for crop irrigation in California expected to lead to an estimated $1.7 billion loss to the state’s agricultural economy
Description: The shortage of water for crop irrigation in California is expected to lead to an estimated $1.7 billion loss to the state’s agricultural economy and leave roughly 14,500 farm workers looking for jobs, according to a preliminary study by the University of California, Davis, Center for Watershed Sciences.  Computer models and recent water delivery amounts were used to tally up the estimated losses in the survey, commissioned by the California Department of Food and Agriculture.  Central Valley farmers may fallow about 6 percent or 410,000 acres because water deliveries will likely be two-thirds of normal this year.  With less irrigation water from surface supplies, farmers are anticipated to pump more groundwater at an estimated cost of $450 million.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 19, 2014

Title: Drought Food Assistance Program boxes available to families in Kern County, California
Description: Community Action Partnership of Kern handed out 30-pound boxes of food to Bakersfield families impacted by drought.  The California Department of Social Services delivered the Drought Food Assistance Program boxes, which contain beans, rice, vegetable soup, canned fruit and spaghetti.  The CAPK has 30,854 such boxes to distribute in Kern County.While many of the families were not facing hardships stemming directly from drought, the families simply had to sign a form attesting that the drought had impacted them.The food bank manager for Community Action Partnership said 800 boxes were given out in Arvin, 600 in Shafter and 250 in Tehachapi.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), May 19, 2014

Title: Frustration in Fresno County, California over Bureau of Reclamation's decision to take water from Millerton Lake for west side farmers
Description: Farmers, water district authorities and city leaders voiced their frustration that the federal Bureau of Reclamation decided to take water from Millerton Lake to give to farmers on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley to meet contractual obligations to the San Joaquin River Exchange Contractors Water Authority.The mayor of Fresno would like a seat at the table with the bureau, city officials and key stakeholders when deciding water issues to help Valley farmers.  The Fresno City Council approved a transfer of 710 acre-feet of water of its San Joaquin River water to the Orange Cove Irrigation District, which provides water for about 28,000 acres in Fresno and Tulare counties.  Water customers in the central San Joaquin Valley who will get no surface water this year were incensed at the bureau’s decision to take water from Millerton Lake.  Even farmers who will benefit from the water transfer from Millerton Lake were unhappy with the bureau moving the water from Millerton Lake.Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 15, 2014

Title: Metropolitan Water District increased rebates on a number of water conservation programs for Southern Californians

The rebate for turf replacement is doubled, and rebates for rain barrels and high-efficiency toilets have been extended.  MWD serves customers in Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, San Diego and Ventura counties.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 15, 2014

Title: Water from Friant Dam to meet contractual obligation to San Joaquin River Exchange Contractors Water Authority in California
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation began releasing more water from Friant Dam near Fresno into the drought-stricken San Joaquin River to supply as much water as has been contracted to the San Joaquin River Exchange Contractors Water Authority on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley.  The water release will be increased from 200 cubic feet per second to 1,200 cfs.In 1939, the Exchange Contractors, which includes the Central California Irrigation District, the San Luis Canal Company, the Firebaugh Canal Water District and the Columbia Canal Company, agreed to accept water from the Delta-Mendota Canal (DMC) from the Bureau of Reclamation rather than get their water using their senior water rights on the San Joaquin and Kings rivers, hence the “exchange.”  When there is not enough water to meet the obligation from the DMC, then Reclamation must release water from Friant Dam to make up the difference.This is the first time in the Central Valley Project history since the Delta-Mendota Canal has been in use that Reclamation has needed to provide extra water from Millerton Lake.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), May 14, 2014

Title: Reduced water allocations for the Klamath Project in southern Oregon, northern California
Description: The Bureau of Reclamation released the 2014 Drought Plan for the Klamath Project because available water supplies were inadequate to satisfy the demands of all Klamath Project contractors during the 2014 spring/summer irrigation season, which runs from March 1 to November 15.  Drought and insufficient participation in the Klamath Water and Power Agency’s Water Users Mitigation Program have brought about the need for Reclamation to formally allocate available water Project supply from Upper Klamath Lake and the Klamath River. Title: San Diego County ablaze with nine wildfires
Description: The San Diego wildfires, fed by high temperatures and dry, gusty winds, caused more than $20 million in damage since they began on May 13.  The fires engulfed 39 square miles and destroyed 47 homes, an 18-unit apartment complex and three businesses.New York Times, May 18, 2014San Diego County was ablaze with nine wildfires that burned more than 14 square miles, driving thousands of people from their homes and closing a college campus and Legoland California.  Gusty winds and high temperatures hampered firefighters battling blazes in San Marcos, Carlsbad, Lakeside, Rancho Bernardo and near Camp Pendleton Marine base.  At least eight homes, two businesses and several other structures were destroyed in the fires.The fire chief of Carlsbad said, "This is May, this is unbelievable. This is something we should see in October.  I haven't seen it this hot, this dry, this long in May."Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 14, 2014
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Sacramento Municipal Utility District to purchase about $35 million worth of electricity
Description: Three years of drought have hydropower production in the Upper American River Project for the Sacramento Municipal Utility District.  The utility is short on hydropower and must purchase about $35 million worth of electricity.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 13, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Two wind-driven brush fires force evacuations in Southern California
Description: Strong winds drove wildfires in San Diego and Santa Barbara counties and were fought aggressive by state and local firefighters.  The wildfires scorched hundreds of acres and caused many evacuations.The brush fire in northern San Diego County charred more than 800 acres, but was checked by Cal Fire and several local departments before too much damage was done.  Three hundred mandatory evacuation calls were made within the city limits, said the San Diego police chief, and the San Diego County sheriff reported that his department made 5,000 calls.  Residents in the Black Mountain Road, Rancho Bernardo, Rancho Penasquitos, Torrey Highlands, Santaluz, Fairbanks Ranch and Rancho Santa Fe areas. The Fairbanks Ranch Country Club was told to evacuate.The wind-driven brush fire in Santa Barbara County blackened 700 acres and forced the evacuation of 1,200 homes and businesses near Lompoc in the San Miguelito Canyon area.  Los Angeles Times, May 13, 2014
Places: San Diego County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Santa Clara Valley Water District’s youth media contest
Description: Youths in Santa Clara County were invited to create a video or poster for entry in the Santa Clara Valley Water District’s youth media contest.  The submissions must feature water-saving tips to raise awareness of the present drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 7, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: California water agencies aim to move water against natural flow of California Aqueduct
Description: Five California water agencies concocted an innovative plan to move water north up the California Aqueduct to water parched crops, although water normally moves north to south in the aqueduct.  State officials are assessing the plan and will give their decision on the plan in June.If approved, water from underground reservoirs in Kern County and other water supplies would be pumped into the aqueduct to raise the water level.  Then diesel pumps would pump the water north over locks against the gravitational pull downhill.  The aim is to move 30,000 acre-feet of water 33 miles from Bakersfield to Kettleman City.Water agencies in the Bay Area are also eager to move water 70 miles against the normal flow of the aqueduct.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 6, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Additional funds for water conservation measures in Santa Clara Valley Water District in California
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District Board of Directors opted to continue the higher rebate amounts for water conservation programs until June 2015.  The public responded very positively to the rebate program and replaced roughly 410,000 square feet of turf from July through October 2014 with ongoing projects to replace another 1.4 million square-feet.  The rebate program also covers irrigation equipment, such as weather based irrigation controllers, rain sensors, high-efficiency nozzles, dedicated landscape meters and efficient sprinklers to curb water use.  To date, about 90,000 pieces of irrigation equipment were or are being replaced.The board also extended the request for 20 percent water conservation until June 2015.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 16, 2014The Santa Clara Valley Water District’s board of directors approved additional funds for water conservation programs as drought continued in the state.  The board authorized up to $1.25 million in additional funds to give customers bigger rebates for numerous conservation measures and to continue the district’s multi-media water conservation campaign.  The increased rebate amounts are intended to encourage residents and businesses to improve their water conservation habits and will remain in effect through September 2014.  Rebates for some programs have doubled, while other rebates have gone up significantly.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 6, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: At least a dozen private wells went dry in Tulare County, California
Description: More than a dozen private wells in Tulare County have gone dry as groundwater levels drop.  Tulare County officials were looking for ways to help the homeowners through federal or state funding because many of the homeowners cannot afford to have their wells drilled deeper, but the officials have not found any funding. Far more people than usual have called the U.S. Department of Agriculture Service Center about funding for private wells, said a rural development specialist.  She was trying to find a suitable funding category, but was not successful.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 5, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA

Title: Burn ban in the Bay Area of California
Description: The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection banned open burning in areas including San Benito County and parts of Alameda, Contra Costa, Santa Clara, San Mateo, Santa Cruz, Stanislaus, San Joaquin and Monterey counties effective May 1.  Drought conditions and an increase in fire activity led Cal Fire to enact the ban.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 2, 2014

Title: 12 million trees killed by drought in Sierra Nevada, Southern California
Description: An April aerial survey performed by the U.S. forest Service found that roughly 12 million trees in California’s forestlands died within the last year due to extreme drought.  In Cleveland, San Bernardino, Angeles and Los Padres National Forests, an estimated 2 million dead trees were seen.  Across 4.1 million acres in the Southern Sierra Nevada, surveyors spotted approximately 10 million dead trees. KPBS-TV PBS San Diego, May 4, 2015
