Title: Dozens of wells dried up in the northern part of San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: Dozens of wells have dried up in the northern part of San Luis Obispo County, frustrating residents who blame vineyards’ water use for the dry wells.  The water level in parts of the county fell by at least 70 feet since 1997, due to drought and growing agricultural and urban demand.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Sept. 1, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Drought damaged grazing land, hindered grass production in San Joaquin County, California
Description: San Joaquin County’s agricultural commissioner requested and received a formal disaster declaration due to drought damage to grazing lands.  Little precipitation fell after December 2012 and did not provide enough moisture for grass production.  He also noted that the past two seasons in a row of below normal rainfall has hindered the recovery of pastures.  TradingCharts (Chicago, Ill.), Aug. 31, 2013
Places: San Joaquin County, CA

Title: The San Juan Water District in Granite Bay, California issued a report stating that water intakes at Folsom Reservoir will be above the water line within months if current weather trends do not change
Description: The San Juan Water District, serving 265,000 customers in Granite Bay and parts of Roseville, Folsom and Orangevale, issued a report stating that water intakes at Folsom Reservoir will be above the water line in April or May if current weather trends do not change.  The water district began encouraging its customers to conserve water since August 2013.  The board will hear recommendations for more stringent water restrictions at its upcoming meeting.  Sacramento Bee (California), Jan. 5, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Placer County, CA, Roseville, CA, Folsom, CA, Orangevale, CA

Title: Nine thousand ducks died from avian botulism at the Tule Lake National Wildlife Refuge near Tule Lake, California
Description: Roughly nine thousand ducks died from avian botulism at the Tule Lake National Wildlife Refuge near Tule Lake, California, due to overcrowding, which facilitates the spread of disease.  The nearby Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge was nearly dry because water shortages in the Klamath Basin meant that the refuge received no water this summer, leading the ducks to congregate at Tule Lake marshes.  Medford Mail Tribune (Ore.), Aug. 29, 2013
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Homeowner reaching last of stored water in Humboldt County, California
Description: We are into the last of our stored water, have cut off the garden, and expect to run out of water before the rains. I take a bath in three inches of water, and double-use any cooking or shower water I can, for flushing, plants, etc. If we buy water it will be $580 for 3200 gallons.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Redway 4.8 WNW on 8/23/2013
Places: Humboldt County, CA

Title: Wildflowers affected by drought in Ventura County, California
Description: Drought conditions have progressed this year to the extent that many common flowering wild plants didn't flower this year.  There were no lupins at all, nor any wild clover, nightshade, maricopa lily, morning glories, five o'clocks, or goldenrod, and very few penstemons (wild snapdragons) and  navaretia.  The scarlet bugles seem unaffected.  The local sage seems to be suffering and many branches on a bush are dying.  There was very little pine pollen this year, when usually the cars get a strong yellow dust.  However, this year the pollen wasn't evident.  There don't appear to be many acorns either, but there is an abundance of wasp galls.  The grass was very sparse and only a few inches tall, barely necessary to cut for fire control.  On the good side of this, there was little grass affected by the blight (the seeds eaten away by a black mold that becomes a black powder when weed-whacked).  There has been no water flowing in the local creek since spring 2012.  Very little of the bunch grass went to seed this year, when usually there are massive amounts of this seed everywhere.  Nearly all of this grass has turned completely brown, and appears dead.  Usually the base of this grass retains some green color, but not this year.  I rely on this grass and the sage for erosion control.   My hillsides had very little growth this spring, and heavy rains this winter would easily bring serious erosion.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Frazier Park 10.7 WSW on 8/22/2013
Places: Ventura County, CA

Title: The Rim Fire burned dry timber, brush in and near Yosemite National Forest in California
Description: The Rim Fire, which blackened more than 400 square miles, burned so intensely over a 60 square mile area that all trees and vegetation were dead.  Researchers say that drought and aridity related to climate change have increased the intensity of wildfires this year.  New York Times (N.Y.), Sept. 18, 2013The Rim Fire burned its way into record books as California’s fourth largest wildfire in history at 348 square miles on Sept. 1.  A spokesman with the U.S. Forest Service stated that $60 million in state and federal funds have been spent fighting the fire.  The blaze was 40 percent contained, but still moving to the northeast.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Sept. 1, 2013The Rim Fire burning in Yosemite National Park has kept away tourists, who would normally pour into the park over the Labor Day weekend.  The fire consumed about 315 square miles, but less than one-fourth of that was in Yosemite.  Trust.org (New York, N.Y.), Aug. 30, 2013The Rim Fire blackened 301 square miles, destroyed 111 structures, including 11 homes and threatened groves of sequoia trees.  Atlanta Journal-Constitution (Ga.), Aug. 28, 2013The Rim Fire charred more than 230 square miles and at least 23 structures and showered ash over the reservoir that provides most of San Francisco’s water.  Firefighters were striving to protect the reservoir, the hydroelectric transmission lines and other utility facilities.  Washington Post (D.C.), Aug. 25, 2013The Rim Fire continued to burn more than 200 square miles in and near Yosemite National Park since the fire began Aug. 17 in a remote canyon in the Stanislaus National Forest.  Firefighters were trying to protect stands of giant sequoia trees, which are some of the oldest and largest living things on the planet.  The blaze became so large, burning through dry timber and brush, that it generated its own weather, making the fire even more difficult to manage.  The fire moved toward the Hetch Hetchy reservoir, the main water and power supply for San Francisco's municipal buildings, the international airport and San Francisco General Hospital.  The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission closed tow hydro-electric stations that use water from the reservoir and turned off power to more than 12 miles of lines.  New London Day (Conn.), Aug. 25, 2013
Places: Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Water to be diverted from lake, residents concerned about water supply in California
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation will be shifting water from Folsom Lake to Southern California, with the lake to drop to 376 feet by December 2013. The general manager of the San Juan Water District is not comfortable with the USBR draining the lake down to 300,000 acre-feet, which is 100,000 acre-feet lower than during the drought of 1976-77. A dry winter could leave Roseville, Folsom and Granite Bay with little water to spare next year.  Auburn Journal (CA), August 16, 2013
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Placer County, CA, Roseville, CA, Folsom, CA

Title: Water to be released from dam to prevent salmon kill in California
Description: More water is being released from Trinity Reservoir to raise the level of the Lower Klamath River to avert a possible fish kill like the one that occurred in 2002. The third largest fall run of Chinook salmon is expected to take place this fall.  San Francisco Indymedia (CA), August 8, 2013
Places: California, San Francisco County, CA, Oregon

Title: Lower water levels facilitate trash removal along waterways in Santa Clara County, California
Description: One hundred tons of trash were removed from Los Gatos Creek and the Guadalupe River over the past two years.  Drought lowered water levels, making it easier to access and collect trash along the waterways.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 8, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Klamath tribal members in the upper Klamath Basin in Oregon eligible for aid from drought relief programs
Description: Klamath tribal members in the upper Klamath Basin who endured water shut-offs to their farms and ranchlands were eligible for assistance from drought relief programs from the Bureau of Reclamation.  The program is for tribal members holding allottee water rights dating back to 1864 on the tribe's former reservation—non-tribal farmers were not eligible.  Tribe members may receive $250 per acre.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), July 31, 2013

Title: Kings River in California not flowing
Description: The Kings River, where people commonly float down the river to cool off, is seeing more use as an off-road trail this year since the river has gone dry.  Hanford Sentinel (Calif.), July 30, 2013
Places: Kings County, CA

Title: Not enough irrigation water to grow marijuana in Plumas National Forest in California
Description: A marijuana garden in the Plumas National Forest was abandoned, possibly due to a shortage of water, theorized the Butte County sheriff. Berkeley East Bay Express (Calif.), July 30, 2013
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: Dry spring affected water volume, recreation on Russian River in Sonoma County, California
Description: A dry spring brought the Russian River to low levels not seen in decades, forcing canoeists above Healdsburg to drag their canoes in a couple of places.The owner of a business that offers kayak and canoe trips said, “I don't tell people it's business as usual. There's less river to paddle in, and in the river channels under the trees our clients have to duck a lot. And they hit sandbars. They have to get out more often.”  She noted that drought has affected her business and fears that another dry winter may drive her out of business.Water releases from Coyote Dam at Lake Mendocino near Ukiah rose 25 percent in late June to boost river flow.Near the Del Rio Woods Beach, a lifeguard reported that the river “is noticeably a lot lower and the water doesn't flow as much. This year it's really bad. This is definitely lower than usual.  There are still swim holes, just not as many”  Canoeing at Del Rio meant pushing off of gravel beds now and then.  One canoeist said, “There's not enough water to flow all the way.  I managed to prod it, dig it along.”  Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), July 28, 2013
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Boat owners at Folsom Lake Marina  in California were told to remove their boats from berths by August 3
Description: Boat owners at Folsom Lake Marina were notified that they must remove their boats from their berths by August 3 because the lake level is receding.  The floating docks will be sitting on the lake bed by early August, and the lake storage will be approximately 412,000 acre-feet.  Normally boats do not need to be removed from their slips until October 1.  "We are dropping about three-quarters of a foot a day," said the marina's manager. "It hurts business all around. We've got a lot of restaurants that depend on the public coming out and using the lake. We've seen a big drop in day use."The Bureau of Reclamation expects that flow in the American River will fall to about 1,000 cubic feet per second—about one-third of the present flow—by October.  The level of Folsom Dam will likely drop to 241,000 acre-feet, or about 25 percent of capacity, in December.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 22, 2013
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: The Mountain Fire burned in the parched San Jacinto Mountains in Riverside County, California
Description: The Mountain Fire blackened thousands of acres of pine forests and chaparral in the San Jacinto Mountains, driving thousands of residents from their homes in Idyllwild.  Firefighters blame drought and dense vegetation untouched by fire for decades for the intensity of the wildfire.  A fire behavior analyst from the Livermore-Pleasanton Fire Department working with an interagency team in the San Jacinto Mountains stated, “I haven’t seen a fire burn with this intensity this early in the fire season, probably in 30 years of firefighting,” and also noted that moisture levels in forest fuels was at historic lows in Southern California.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), July 21, 2013
Places: Riverside County, CA, Idyllwild, CA

Title: Fire forces residents to evacuate town, damages area, California
Description: The Mountain Fire blackened more than 22,800 acres and forced more than 6,000 people to flee. A Forest Service spokeswoman said that the wind-driven blaze was burning in timber and shrub land that was exceedingly dry after the dry winter. It has cost $5.5 million to battle the fire, according to the U.S. Forest Service.  NBC (NY), California, July 18, 2013

Description: The Klamath Basin watermaster finished regulation in the last week and is monitoring stream flows to see that required minimum flows have been met.  He said that in the basin, only Crooked Creek was meeting required flows.  The amount of the required flow decreases on July 1 and August 1. Title: The California Water Resources Control Board warned water rights holders in the Sacramento Valley that curtailments may be in the offing
Description: The California Water Resources Control Board warned water rights holders in the Sacramento Valley that curtailments may be in the offing, given the low runoff, if there isn’t more water conservation. "This is really a heads-up for a potentially critical condition," said the assistant deputy director for water rights at the board.  The last time those with “riparian” and “pre-1914” water rights faced curtailments was during the 1976-77 drought.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 17, 2013

The average number of well permit applications during a normal year is around 50.  The county received 165 applications during the 2013-14 fiscal year.Santa Maria Sun (Calif.), Oct. 16, 2014

Title: Drought allows oyster farmer in Marin County, California to work more days
Description: A Marin County oyster farmer credits the drought with allowing him to harvest oysters more and having to stop less frequently when rains wash unwanted bacteria into the bay.  He normally has about 90 days per year when he cannot work, but drought has cut the number down to about 30 days when runoff keeps him from harvesting oysters.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 3, 2014

Title: Fewer people purchase annual and boat passes in San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: The number of annual passes and boat passes sold between July 2013 and February 2014 slumped 43 percent, compared to the previous year, said San Luis Obispo County parks officials. Title: Drought improved Lake Tahoe's clarity
Description: Average water clarity at Lake Tahoe increased to nearly 78 feet in 2014, up from more than 70 feet in 2013.   During drought, there is less stormwater runoff to cloud the lake water.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 25, 2015

A park spokesperson said that park staff will be on high alert on July 4 to take quick action against any fires that might pop up and also said that campgrounds could close early on July 4. Title: Campfire restrictions in San Bernardino National Forest in California
Description: Dry conditions in the San Bernardino National Forest prompted warnings to visitors to keep vehicles on paved roads, be especially careful with open fires and extinguish cigarettes in ashtrays rather than throwing them out of car windows.  Violators may be fined up to $10,000 or face six months imprisonment.  Campfires are permitted at developed camp sites and within fire rings and camp stoves.  KCBQ (San Diego, Calif.), June 21, 2013
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Irrigation shutoffs in Klamath Reclamation Project in southern Oregon, northern California
Description: The chairman for the Klamath Tribes and the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation commissioner announced calls on water rights for rivers flowing into Upper Klamath Lake, which may leave up to 58,000 acres without irrigation water by the bureau’s calculations.  The tribes have the oldest water rights and want to maintain adequate flows in the Wood, Williamson, Sprague and Sycan rivers for fish, such as the endangered suckers and redband tout.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation uses its water for the Klamath Reclamation Project, an irrigation project supplying water for 225,000 acres straddling the Oregon-California border, and for wildlife refuges that support migrating waterfowl.  The local water master, working for the Oregon Department of Water Resources (ODWR), must begin checking river flows and notifying those with junior water rights to stop pumps and close headgates on diversion dams until the bureau’s and tribes’ water rights are met.  It may take several weeks to make all notifications to increase river flow.  The ODWR has three teams of two people each to visit junior water rights holders and shut off water.  The sheriff will be notified of the teams’ whereabouts at all times for the teams’ safety.  The suspension of junior water rights will continue through the summer as flows in the river fall.  One Klamath County commissioner warned that violence could easily accompany these calls on water rights.  A rancher stated that the irrigation shutoffs will bring economic disaster because livestock producers will not be able to feed their herds.  One rancher worries about where to find decent pasture for her cattle and sent some to family ranches.  They will need to begin purchasing hay in roughly six weeks.  It would cost an estimated $27 million to feed hay to the more than 70,000 cattle on lands affected by the calls.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), June 11, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR, Lake County, OR

Title: The Hathaway fire charred at least 2,372 acres in the Banning Pass in southern California
Description: The Hathaway fire burned 2,372 acres through the evening of June 11 and was 30 percent contained, according to the U.S. Forest Service’s Inciweb website.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), June 11, 2013The Hathaway fire charred at least 1,650 acres on the Morongo Indian Reservation north of Banning since June 9.  The fire, which was 25 percent contained on the evening of June 10, was burning through heavy chaparral and drought-and bark beetle-damaged timber.  The South Coast Air Quality Management District  issued a smoke advisory for people in northern parts of the Banning Pass and around Big Bear Lake to alert them to deteriorating air quality.  Officials hope that the fire might be completely contained by the end of June.  When the fire began, the region was in severe drought, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor released June 6, 2013.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), June 10, 2013
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Irrigators in the Klamath Irrigation District in Oregon and California to receive two-thirds of normal water delivery
Description: More groundwater is being pumped in the Klamath Irrigation District and fields were left fallow to compensate for water allocations that are about two-thirds of normal.  Peak snowfall was about 68 percent of average, and rainfall has been about 50 percent of normal.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 6, 2013

Title: The Powerhouse wildfire burned at least 25,000 acres north of Los Angeles, California
Description: The Powerhouse wildfire near Lake Hughes, north of L.A., burned 25,000 acres, including six houses by the evening of June 2.  At least 1,000 other homes were threatened by the fire, which prompted the evacuation of more than 2,000 people.  The wildfire was 20 percent contained and may not be brought under control for a week, officials said.  High temperatures and wind variability have driven the fire in an area that the U.S. Drought Monitor characterizes as being in severe drought.  New York Times (N.Y.), June 3, 2013

Title: Steelhead salmon rescued from dry Carmel River in Monterey County, California
Description: A 13-mile dry stretch of the Carmel River forced the rescue of steelhead salmon from the river in the summer of 2013 and relocating them to better parts of the river.  Washington Post (D.C.), Feb. 10, 2014

Title: Ninety-five percent of California beaches received grades of A or B for water quality during the summer of 2013
Description: Ninety-five percent of California beaches received grades of A or B for water quality during the summer of 2013 when there was little rain to wash pollutants to the sea.  This represents a 2 percent improvement over 2012, according to the annual Beach Report Card by Heal the Bay, an environmental group.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 22, 2014

Title: Many California farmers producing more, using less water with drip-tape
Description: Drought and limited water allocations pushed California farmers to seek more efficient ways to irrigate their crops.  Some farmers plant crops that need less water, store excess water in groundwater reserves during wetter years, try growing genetically altered crops that lose less water through evapotranspiration, leave land fallow or use drip-tape to direct water where it can be better used with less water waste.  Roughly one-third of the 9.4 million acres of irrigated land in California is irrigated with drip-tape to conserve water.  In addition, yields are higher using drip-tape than they are with other irrigation methods.  A grower northwest of Visalia estimated that he uses 20 to 40 percent less water with drip-tape.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 30, 2013
Places: California, Tulare County, CA

Title: A wildfire in the Los Padres National Forest in California charred 2.8 square miles
Description: A wildfire in the Los Padres National Forest charred 2.8 square miles of parched chaparral, oak and pine, leading to evacuations of about 50 cabins, vacation rentals and homes.  The blaze claimed two vehicles and a U.S. Forest Service garage.  The Santa Barbara County fire captain said, “There's a lot of dry vegetation in its path.  It's still spring — it's not even summer — and it's burning like it's August or September."  The fire was 10 percent contained on May 28.  Washington Post (D.C.), May 27, 2013
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Lower waters bring early sightings of herons seeking fish in Mendocino County, California

Earlier sightings of herons - who take advantage of lower waters to fish.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Laytonville 1.1 SW on 5/13/2013

Title: Homeowner irrigating permanent plantings, pine trees dying in Mariposa County, California

We have had to irrigate permanent plantings,  and pine trees are dying, as they did last year.  The grass is very low, and the snow pack in the high country, from which farmers and all others get their water, is very far from normal.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Mariposa 3.7 NNW on 5/11/2013

Title: Dry fuels feed Ventura County, California, wildfire
Description: Dry fuels and low relative humidity led to a wildfire that has burned at least 10,000 acres and damaged 15 houses, 5 commercial properties, and 15 outbuildings in Ventura County, California. For more information: http://ktla.com/2013/05/03/brush-fire-burning-off-101-in-camarillo/#axzz2SFXol2SDFrom a NOAA employee in Hanford, California, on May 2, 2013.The Springs fire with flames 20 feet high drove thousands from their homes on the morning of May 2 and charred more than 6,500 acres in the span of a few hours. Title: Threat of Valley fever requires relocation of high-risk inmates from prisons in the San Joaquin Valley in California
Description: Thousands of high-risk inmates must be removed from the Avenal and Coalinga prisons in the San Joaquin Valley, due to the increasing incidence of Valley fever, caused by an airborne fungus.  The order is complicated by the fact that California prisons are already overcrowded and the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation is to reduce the state prison population by 9,000 inmates by December 2013.Valley fever cases are highest in Arizona (70 percent of cases) and California (25 percent), according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.  Most incidences of Valley fever occur in the central San Joaquin Valley, with the highest rates of illness at the Avenal and Coalinga prisons, where the disease contributed to the deaths of 24 inmates between 2006 and 2011.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 29, 2013
Places: Fresno County, CA, Coalinga, CA, Kings County, CA, Avenal, CA

Title: Drought leaves Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve barren
Description: Drought prevented orange poppies from flourishing in the Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve this year.  Instead, the area looks like a “brown shag rug” and, consequently, has not drawn many visitors.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), April 19, 2013
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Cal Fire began deploying fire crews ahead of schedule in SoCal
Description: Cal Fire began deploying fire crews ahead of schedule since dry conditions have resulted in greater fire danger and more fires than usual early in the year.   Brush in the hills of Los Angeles has dried out more quickly than usual; Ventura County firefighters say the arid conditions resemble that of June or July; and the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection has responded to 150 more fires in 2013 than it had by this time last year.  Southern California is on track to have its fourth driest year since 1877.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), April 19, 2013
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Joshua trees in southern California, southern Nevada and western Arizona blooming abundantly
Description: Drought conditions may be the reason Joshua trees in Joshua Tree National Park and parts of Nevada and Arizona are producing abundant blossoms, desert ecologists think, as the area undergoes two years of drought.  Many other plant species demonstrate a greater effort at reproduction during drought to ensure the species survives.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), April 10, 2013
Places: La Paz County, AZ, Maricopa County, AZ, Mohave County, AZ, Yuma County, AZ, Inyo County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, Esmeralda County, NV, Nye County, NV

Title: California State Water Project water allocations reduced from an estimated 40 percent to 35 percent
Description: The last snow survey in California revealed just 17 percent of normal snowpack, said California Department of Water Resources (DWR).  Due to the slim snowpack, the DWR said that it may be able to provide just 35 percent of the requested water amounts from the State Water Project to the 29 agencies that buy water from the DWR.  Water allotments have not been so low since 2008.  The projected runoff from the Colorado River into Lake Powell is 44 percent and has been below normal for 11 of the last 14 years.  The limited water supply in California means that the state will have to use stored water from large reservoirs in southern California, such as Diamond Valley Lake, which contains 800,000 acre-feet of water.  KPBS-TV PBS San Diego (Calif.), May 3, 2013.The California Department of Water Resources announced that State Water Project water allocations were reduced from an estimated 40 percent to 35 percent since the average snowpack was 57 percent of normal for mid to late March.  Napa Valley Register (Calif.), March 27, 2013.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Pollen count high in the San Joaquin Valley in California
Description: The warm, dry spring in the Fresno area prompted plants to ratchet up the pollen production, which is a survival mechanism many plants employ during drought.  As a result, many allergy sufferers were exceptionally miserable and will likely be for a while.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 8, 2013
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: California ranchers have to feed, water cattle
Description: Poor rains during the spring left pastures rather dry and offering little for grazing this fall, said a University of California Cooperative Extension livestock and natural resources advisor for Yuba, Sutter and Butte counties.  Fall rains, too, have been disappointing, and did not promote much grass growth, leaving ranchers to buy dry feed and hay, although hay prices were high in California, due to poor production.  Stock water supplies were low also.A dryland cattle producer in Riverside and Tulare counties said that he began feeding hay in September and buys culled oranges, lemons, avocadoes and other fruit and vegetable byproducts to feed his cattle until he has better range for his cattle.  To conserve feed, he weaned his calves early and sold about 25 percent of his cows.  He had already culled 15 percent of his cattle in 2012 and sold all of his heifers during the last two years, leaving him no replacements.A San Joaquin County cattle producer moved his cattle to several properties to allow them to graze and stretch the feed.  He also sent some yearlings to feedlots early.  A cattle producer in Nevada County reported that drought has driven up his production costs, forcing him to leave his cattle on the range longer and buy more hay than usual.A Santa Cruz County cattle producer began feeding hay in September and hopes there will be adequate grass in January or February to feed the livestock because he’ll be out of feed by then.  He has thinned his herd by about 10 percent and purchased about 30 percent more hay.  Central Valley Business Times (Calif.), Dec. 4, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Marshes mostly dry in Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge in southern Oregon, northern California
Description: Very few birds visited the Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge because its marshes have mostly dried up for the earliest dry date in the last 70 years.  The refuge has not received water since March, leaving no water to draw migratory birds, despite being on the Pacific Flyway.  Indian tribes and agriculture have older water rights than the refuge does.  The manager of the Klamath refuge said that the park needs about 95,000 acre-feet of water to operate at full capacity, but often does not get the water it needs.  The refuge received 3,700 acre-feet in 2010 and 24,000 acre-feet in 2012.  Portland Oregonian, Hillsboro Argus, Oregon Live.com (Ore.), July 7, 2013
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Small businesses in eight California counties were eligible for low-interest loans from the Small Business Administration
Description: Small businesses in eight California counties were eligible for low-interest loans from the Small Business Administration for financial loss due to drought from Feb. 12 through April 8, 2013.  The counties include Monterey, San Luis Obispo, Fresno, Kern, Kings, San Benito, Santa Barbara and Santa Cruz.  The declaration makes small businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, and nurseries eligible for loans through the Economic Injury Disaster Loan program.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 16, 2013
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Monterey County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA

Title: Sonoma County, California, little vegetation for animals
Description: We live on land that is protected by a conservation easement that is intended to preserve natural open space. During a drought, the impacts to natural resources on this property reflect the effects on the broader ecosystem. As a retired wildlife biologist I notice the frogs and turles in our streams are concentrated around a few bedrock pools, which increases their vulnerability to predators. Herbivores are stressed as nutritious green feed is scarce. Trees, like buckeyes and blue oaks, which here in California are adapted to dry summers have already shown fall color and leaf drop, about a month or two early.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Geyserville 10.6 WNW on 8/25/2013
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Small businesses in Kern and Kings counties in California eligible for low-interest loans from the Small Business Administration
Description: Small businesses in Kern and Kings counties in California were eligible for low-interest loans from the Small Business Administration for financial loss due to drought from Jan. 15 through March 11, 2013.  The declaration makes small businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, and nurseries eligible for loans through the Economic Injury Disaster Loan program.  Farmers and ranchers should not apply.  Applications must be received by Nov. 13.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), May 1, 2013
Places: Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA

Title: Drought-related USDA disaster declarations in 2013

Farmers in affected counties have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for low-interest emergency loans. For more information, agricultural producers should contact their Farm Service Agency office. From Farm Service Agency press releases, beginning Jan. 9, 2013.

Title: California almonds slightly smaller in 2013
Description: California produced 1.88 billion pounds of almonds in 2013, but the nuts were slightly smaller than usual because the water supplies were scarce in 2013.  The state endured its driest stretch in 90 years between January and May, dropping reservoir levels and limiting water allocations, according to the Bureau of Reclamation.  Lakeland Ledger (Fla.), Jan. 17, 2014
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Many Monterey pines dead in Cambria Pines by the Sea, California
Description: Many of the tall Monterey pines in Cambria Pines by the Sea have succumbed to drought.  In 2013, one-quarter of the town’s trees died, and most of the remaining trees were brown and brittle.  Some of the trees have fallen over and others were felled for public safety.  Los Angeles Times, Nov. 4, 2014
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Cambria Pines, CA

Title: The California State Water Project dropped its water allocations by 35 percent, due to below normal precipitation
Description: The California State Water Project dropped its water allocations by 35 percent, due to below normal precipitation between January and June 2013, which was the driest in the state’s recorded history.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Oct. 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Orange County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Solano County, CA, Yuba City, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Sonoma County, California, dry streams cause stress to critters, low well water causes residents to conserve
Description: This has been a very dry end to our usual rainy season that runs from October to May, and a very dry start to the coming season which usually brings appreciable rain in October and November before peaking in December and January. Streams are dry, and frogs and turtles are clustered in a few bedrock pools and seeps. Wildlife like raccoons are coming to and digging around landscape plants that are on drip emitters. Our wells are only able to pump water for a few minutes out of each hour, so we are diligently conserving. We are exploring drilling an additional well.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Geyserville 10.6 WNW on 11/13/2013
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Drought closed marina and store at Santa Margarita Lake in San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: The Santa Margarita Lake Marina & Mini Mart plans to close on April 18 because drought drastically reduced the number of customers coming to the lake, which was at 37.6 percent of capacity.The marina store owner explained the reason for closing by saying, “I’ve had one customer this morning.  Three yesterday. This is spring break. Do you see anyone here?”The gross revenue in 2013 was $50,000, compared to a high of $140,000 in 2006.  He brought in $4,500 over Memorial Day weekend in 2013, which was less than half of the $11,000 he made on the same weekend in 2006.San Luis Obispo County Tribune (Calif.), March 28, 2014
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Tehama County, California agricultural losses from drought estimated at $6.9 million
Description: Drought cost Tehama County $6.9 million in agricultural losses in 2013.  Much of the damage is to 924,000 acres of rangeland for a 70 percent loss, amounting to roughly $6,145,000, a 50 percent loss in barley production at a value of roughly $275,000 and a 40 percent loss to the hay crop, costing an estimated $523,000.  Agricultural Commissioner, Rick Gurrola, sought a disaster declaration for Tehama County, where precipitation was about 20 percent of normal for the first half of 2013.  Red Bluff Daily News (Calif.), July 3, 2013
Places: Tehama County, CA

Title: Placer County, California, increased fire danger, ski resorts losing business
Description: The calendar year 2013 (which is not the water monitoring year) was the driest consecutive 12 months in recent memory. Major impact for my specific area is an elevated fire danger; marginal snow conditions at the ski resorts reducing the number of tourist & impacting revenue for lodging, restaurants, sporting goods retailers, chain installers, gas stations, tow truck operators, & the ski resorts; & me, personally, income from lack of overtime plowing snow. Normally I get out to ski 50 to 80 times a year.  As of 1/10/14 I have yet to go out.It is a boon for the California highway department as they are saving on all those wages, traction materials, repairs to road surface & guard rails, & maintenance to snow removal vehicles. Insurance companies will see a dramatic drop in claims based upon much less treacherous driving conditions. The highway patrol will also see a dramatic drop in citations due to those safer driving conditions. The locale that I am at the midpoint of the Sierra Nevada, at the crest. This is the "reservoir" of water for virtually the entire 35 million residents of the State of California. Without even a marginal supply of water, the monetary impact will be unimaginable. When it snows up at my location, it's raining in the lower elevations. And to think that 3 short years ago, I was reporting a snow depth in March of 2011 of over 250". Just give us 10% of that right now & we would be ecstatic.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Soda Springs 1.5 SSW on 1/11/2014
Places: Placer County, CA

Title: More fires in the San Mateo-Santa Cruz Cal Fire unit in 2013 than in previous year
Description: The San Mateo-Santa Cruz Cal Fire unit has responded to 344 fires that charred 152 acres in 2013, which was considerably higher than fire statistics from 2012 when 296 blazes burned about 33 acres.  So far, 2013 has been one of the driest years on record in California.  SFExaminer.com (Calif.), Nov. 18, 2013
Places: San Mateo County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA

Title: Low creek in Trinity County, California, has algae bloom on submerged sticks and rocks
Description: We've had below-normal rain and snow this season, after the big storms of late December.  Brown's Creek is just 2" above November benchmark low.  The snowpack is almost nonexistent.  Most residents along this watershed rely on it exclusively for water.  Fish migration/spawning will be affected by low water.  We're already seeing an algae bloom on submerged sticks and rocks.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Douglas City 2.4 SW on 4/7/2013
Places: Trinity County, CA

Title: Wells going dry in San Diego County, California
Description: Groundwater levels in San Diego County dropped so much in 2013 that the county had the fifth most wells that were dug deeper.A residential well in Alpine went dry, forcing the owner to dig deeper to reach water again.The manager of a San Diego-area water well drilling business recommended that everyone pray for rain as water supplies above and below ground become depleted.ABC10 (San Diego, Calif.), May 5, 2014
Places: San Diego County, CA, Alpine, CA

Title: Grass growth, mustard crop decreased in Sonoma County, California
Description: Less grass growth in field. Mustard crop in garden 1/4 of what it was last year (mustard is turned under in spring as green manure).  Additional pumping of well water for garden and decorative plants.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Sebastopol 3.7 WSW on 4/5/2013
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Forest mortality rose 300 percent in California's Yosemite National Park
Description: Drought and an army of pine beetles increased forest mortality 300 percent in Yosemite National Park from 2013 to 2014, said federal officials.  Those large bands of dead trees may fuel an active fire season. Los Angeles Times, March 28, 2015
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Drought, wildfire led to turtle die-off in Elizabeth Lake in Los Angeles County, California
Description: Nearly all of the turtles living in Elizabeth Lake in the Angeles National Forest in northern Los Angeles County died after wildfire and years of drought.  Scientists began studying the turtles in 2014 and noted that ash from wildfires hurt water quality, which was already poor, due to the drought.  YubaNet (Calif.), April 11, 2017
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Thousands of Chinook salmon eggs and newly hatched salmon died in the Sacramento River in California this year
Description: Thousands of Chinook salmon eggs and newly hatched salmon died in the Sacramento River this year, due to lower water releases from Shasta and Keswick dams and little contribution from the river’s tributaries.  An environmental scientist with the California Department of Fish and Wildlife stated that 20 to 40 percent of the salmon nests were exposed when the river level fell in early November.  Water Environment Federation (Alexandria, Va.), Dec. 12, 2013
Places: Sacramento County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Saltwater intrusion a greater problem for California's Salinas Valley amid drought
Description: Seawater intrusion went deeper into Salinas Valley’s underground water supply as groundwater levels dropped between 2013 and 2015 amid California’s years long drought.   Monterey County Herald (Calif.), July 11, 2017
Places: Monterey County, CA, Salinas, CA

Title: Christmas trees in California growing slower amid drought
Description: Fewer big Christmas trees can be found in California after five years of below-normal precipitation, but tree growers were selling what they had.  A Christmas tree farmer in El Dorado County said demand exceeded supply, but that they would be open while they had trees to sell.  The growth of firs and other traditional Christmas trees has been slowed significantly by the meager rain and snowfall in recent years, so it takes longer to get a “full-sized” tree.  Drought has been particularly hard on Noble fir trees, with many of them bearing plenty of brown needles.  Silver tip firs, Douglas firs, white firs and native incense cedars have tolerated the scarce precipitation better.  Drought in 2013 and 2014 cost tree growers thousands of seedlings planted in those years.  In recent years, growers have begun buying water to keep the trees growing.  Raleigh News & Observer (N.C.), Dec. 5, 2016
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Hay thefts continue in many parts of the country because drought this summer prevented hay from growing well, driving hay prices higher
Description: Hay thefts continue in many parts of the country because drought this summer prevented hay from growing well, driving hay prices higher.  Three hay growers in Butte County, California have had hay stolen repeatedly from their fields, stated a Custom Hay operator.  Hay sells for more than $200 per ton in California.  In Tillman County, Oklahoma, the clever sheriff planted a GPS unit in a bale of hay located in a field where hay rustlers had already struck, hoping that they would strike again.  He managed to catch the thieves red-handed.  Grass hay prices in Kansas have nearly tripled from about $15 to $25 per bale to $65 to $75 for a bale.  Alfalfa prices rose from about $45 to $60 per bale to $140 to $150 per bale.  The Missouri Farm Bureau president stated that hay thieves were a problem in his state.  Sheriff’s deputies in Butler County, Kansas were patrolling county roads to stem hay thefts.  The Drought Impact Reporter previously noted that hay thefts were occurring in Missouri; New Mexico; Larimer County, Colorado; Butler County, Kansas; New Mexico; and Texas.  NPR (Washington, D.C.), Dec. 5, 2012
Places: Butte County, CA, Butler County, KS, Tillman County, OK

Title: Drought affecting sheep flock in Placer and Solano counties in California
Description: Because of the drought, we have reduced the size of our commercial sheep flock by 37% over the last year.  We have a lower lambing percentage this spring, and we're planning on selling all of our lambs at weaning (rather than finishing them on irrigated pasture).From a farmer/rancher in Auburn, California, on May 14, 2014
Places: Placer County, CA, Solano County, CA

Title: Drought limited the production of natural forage and food for black bears in the Eastern Sierra region of California
Description: Drought limited the production of natural forage and food for black bears in the Eastern Sierra region of California, prompting the U.S. Forest Service to warn forest visitors to keep their food and trash properly locked up to avoid bears becoming habituated to human food.  The Mammoth Times (Calif.), Aug. 8, 2012
Places: Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Drought, land development reduced the supply of milkweed at Pismo State Beach Monarch Butterfly Grove in California
Description: Drought and land development have reduced the supply of milkweed at Pismo State Beach Monarch Butterfly Grove over the past five years.  As a result, fewer monarch butterflies, which feed on milkweed, were returning to Pismo Beach to mate during the fall and winter.   About 23,000 monarchs visited during the last butterfly season between October 2011 and February 2012.  In 1990, at least 200,000 butterflies wintered there.  Adobe Press (Calif.), Nov. 6, 2012
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: The decline of Lake Hemet in Riverside County, California
Description: The Lake Hemet Municipal Water District stopped drawing water from the lake in late 2012 as the volume of water fell to 50 percent of capacity.  In February 2014, the lakebed was exposed and overgrown with weeds since rains have not replenished the lake.  Paddleboats cannot be used in the lake while it is so shallow.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Feb. 26, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: California poultry farm driven to bankruptcy as grain prices rise
Description: The rising price of grain pushed a poultry farm in California to file for bankruptcy.  The $1.8 million weekly expense for feed was too much for this farm that was founded in 1928 and houses 1.9 million turkeys and 600,000 chickens.  The poultry farm shelled out between $7 and $8 per bushel for corn and more than $500 per ton for soybean meal this year.  Soybean meal sold for about $300 per ton in the previous two years.  Wall Street Journal (N.Y.), Oct. 10, 2012
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Fresno, California, low water levels lead to no rafting on rivers
Description: Very dry conditions across the Valley with little snow pack this past winter to feed the rivers, lakes, etc. Low levels exist at all the lakes in the Central Sierras. Watching out for newly exposed rocks is a major concern while going out fishing. People I know haven't been able to raft on the Merced River or the Kings River because of low water levels, too.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Clovis 2.9 N on 8/16/2012
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Yosemite Falls and other water falls in the Yosemite National Park in California temporarily dry
Description: Yosemite Falls stopped flowing after an arid winter and summer allowed the falls to run dry in July, which is months earlier than when they usually stop flowing.   Recent rains revived the Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls, Bridalveil and other waterfalls in Yosemite National Park.  The Merced River at the Happy Isles gauging station fell to less than 4 cubic feet per second in October, but did not rise much from the recent rain.  Merced Sun-Star (Calif.), Nov. 23, 2012
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: USDA Announces Streamlined Disaster Designation Process
Description: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack July 11 announced a package of program improvements that will deliver faster and more flexible assistance to farmers and ranchers devastated by natural disasters. Vilsack announced three significant improvements to decades-old USDA programs and processes related to Secretarial disaster designations: a final rule that simplifies the process for Secretarial disaster designations and will result in a 40 percent reduction in processing time for most counties affected by disasters; a reduced interest rate for emergency loans that effectively lowers the current rate from 3.75 percent to 2.25 percent; and a payment reduction on Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) lands qualified for emergency haying and grazing in 2012, from 25 to 10 percent. ... The final rule for Secretarial disaster designations is amended as follows: 1) Nearly automatically qualifies a disaster county once it is categorized by the U.S. Drought Monitor as a severe drought for eight consecutive weeks during the growing season. Effective July 12, 1,016 primary counties in 26 states will be designated as natural disaster areas, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low interest emergency loans from USDA’s Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility requirements are met. 2) Streamlines the USDA Secretarial designation process, which is expected to provide better service to farmers and ranchers by reducing by approximately 40 percent the amount of time required for designating a disaster area. 3) Removes the requirement that a request for a disaster designation be initiated by a state governor or Indian tribal council, increasing the likelihood that counties will be covered. Indian tribal councils and governors may still submit a request for a designation, but it will not be required in order to initiate a disaster declaration. ... http://www.usda.gov/documents/disaster-fast-track-2012.pdf http://www.fsa.usda.gov/Internet/FSA_File/fast_trk_primary_contig_cos.pdfUSDA FSA press release, July 12, 2011

Title: Water selling for $5,000 per acre-foot in San Bernardino County, California
Description: Several water purchases, in which the Mojave Water Agency had a part, were in the same price range as Hesperia’s water deal, in which the community paid $5,000 per acre-foot, said the watermaster services manager for the MWA.  Water prices have hovered around $4,700 to $5,000 per acre-foot since the latter half of 2012.Hesperia Star (Calif.), March 18, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Sonoma County, California, skinny deer, lots of fires
Description: Normal summer-dry season in north-coastal California is made a little dryer by somewhat below-normal winter precipitation, and a persistent hot, dry, high-pressure area to the east. This puts nutritional stress on herbivorous wildlife and deer I've been watching are showing ribs.  Stream flows are reduced, and returning salmonids this fall may be delayed or unable to pass barriers, either thermal or physical.  We are experiencing an active fire season, and low humidity and very high temperatures are making fire-fighting difficult. CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Geyserville 10.6 WNW on 8/14/2012
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Not enough water to meet irrigation demand in the Klamath Basin in southern Oregon and northern California
Description: More irrigators were needed to sign up for a land-idling program to reduce the need for irrigation water in the Klamath Basin because there was not enough water to meet irrigation demand this season.  The Bureau of Reclamation estimated on May 22 that there would be a shortfall of about 70,000 acre-feet for the Klamath Reclamation Project over the summer.  Normally the project requires at least 400,000 acre-feet during a non-drought year.  Farmers may still enroll for the land-idling program with the Klamath Water and Power Agency through June 1.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), May 22, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR, Lake County, OR

Title: Mariposa County officials requested that the state of California seek federal disaster status for the county
Description: Mariposa County officials requested that the state of California seek federal disaster status for the county’s ranchers who anticipate a difficult season.  Rain did not fall at the appropriate time to promote enough grass and forage growth for cattle, leaving livestock producers to purchase expensive hay.  Forage plants, such as vetch, clover and filaree, matured early and began to produce seeds, achieving 22 percent of normal growth, leaving producers with a forage loss of about $4.75 million in Mariposa County.  Grasses grew two to three inches on average, instead of a more normal growth of 12 to 14 inches.  Mariposa Gazette (Calif.), April 26, 2012
Places: Mariposa County, CA

Title: Ventura County, California, more bark beetles than ever before, fewer wildflowers blooming, fewer insects and reptiles
Description: There has been no rain, other than a trace on a few days, since mid April.  In addition, it was a very dry winter with very little snow compared to other winters.  Our Spring had short grass and about half the quantity of stalks.  The bunch grass was completely dried by mid June, when usually it's not dry until mid July.  The other grasses had gone to seed before June, when usually they go to seed by mid to late June.  There seemed to be not as much pine pollen this year, and I have seen many many more bark beetles everywhere this year than in years past.  In fact, this is the first year in 12 years that I have lived in this area where I saw more than just one or two bark beetles.  This year I have seen hundereds of bark beetles caught inside of boxes and buckets and in cracks and crevaces, in the dry rain gauge, etc.  I'm hoping that I don't lose any pinions to the beetles.  I have noticed that very, very few wildflowers bloomed this year, including the penstemons, lupins, mariposa lilies, maracopa poppies, and california poppies.  In regards to insects: there are much fewer yellow jackets, sweat flies, spiders, june beetles, and moths.  I haven't seen any wasps either, not the tiny ones on the oaks, or the bigger ones.  I haven't seen a scorpion or a jerusalem cricket.  It still sounds like there's lots of crickets at night time.  The dry spell along with the unusually hot May and June probably contributed to the early seeding of the grasses.  I can't say about the birds, because I stopped feeding them this spring.  I can't afford it right now.  I haven't seen any reptiles at all this spring or summer.  Not a lizard or snake.  Every year we see lots of lizards and a few snakes, but not this year.  Not a single reptile.  Hope that comment doesn't conjure up a rattler now....  The burned out forest (Day Fire in '06) is now six years later but after this dry spring and summer, it looks like the fire just happened a year or two ago.  Most of the burned trees are still standing.  No woodpeckers or flickers this year.  The creek bed (Lockwood Creek that crosses over Boy Scout Camp Rd), hasn't had water flowing in it for months.  No thistle plants, when usually I have one or two dozen of them.   This means that there are no humming birds either.  It's a very dry, lean year for plants, animals, and people.  This year it seems that most life forms have it real tough.  A nice thing for me is the competition between McDonalds and Jack-in-the-Box offering $1 large soft drinks.  That makes long drives much more pleasant.  I'm very worried about fires.  Last year the forest service had spotters along Lockwood Valley Road but possible budget cuts have prevented this from happening this year.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Frazier Park 10.7 WSW on 8/10/2012
Places: Ventura County, CA

Title: Dry conditions lead to poor kayaking in Sonoma County, California
Description: It has been a cool summer overall. Last year we had early rains, which destroyed a lot of the wine grape harvest, but had basically a drought year from then on. Now is harvest season again, and we have a forecast of showers starting tonight. So far the sky is clear. We'll see. Early rains destroy the harvest, but the area needs rain. Wine or survival? As a swimmer, I have noticed that the outdoor pools have been cool, which I hate.Kayaking has been poor due to dried up creeks and an unpredictable Russian River. Another dry year may have us conserving water.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Forestville 0.7 SW on 10/9/2012
Places: Sonoma County, CA, Forestville, CA

Title: Many waterfowl perished from avian cholera in northern California, southern Oregon
Description: Drought contributed to the spread of avian cholera, leading to the deaths of approximately 10,000 snow geese, Ross’s geese, pintail ducks and other migrating waterfowl at the Lower Klamath and Tule Lake national wildlife refuges in northern California.  While some number of birds commonly die from avian cholera each year, the outbreak was much worse this year because a lack of water reduced the spatial extent of the marshes by half, crowding the birds into a smaller area.  The close proximity of the birds allowed the disease to spread more easily.  The refuge manager anticipated the deaths of 15,000 or so birds before the outbreak was over.   Water delivery to the refuges have resumed.   Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), March 30, 2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Anxiety over water supply in the Klamath River Basin in southern Oregon and northern California
Description: Klamath County commissioners made a drought declaration to pave the way for possible state and federal drought declarations and access to aid programs and pumping from emergency wells since there was insufficient water to satisfy farmers and coho salmon in the Klamath River Basin.  Meanwhile, officials in Humboldt County, California and the Hoopa Valley Tribe were seeking more water for salmon in the Trinity River because three times the highest recorded number of salmon was expected to spawn this season.   The executive director of the Klamath Water Users Association stated that farmers were in a bind, not knowing whether to plant crops or farm outside of the project, since farmers with junior water rights were cautioned by the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation that they may not receive irrigation water this growing season.  The decision on water allocation will not be made until April.  San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), March 21, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR, Lake County, OR

Title: Drought emergency declaration in Marin County, California
Description: The Marin County Board of Supervisors declared a drought emergency in hopes of receiving state or federal aid if and when it becomes available.  Pasture grass production was down 50 percent from the lack of rain, increasing dairy ranchers' production costs.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 21, 2012
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: California resort still making snow
Description: Inadequate snowfall led the China Peak Mountain Resort to continue making snow through the winter, stated the marketing and retail manager.  Visitation was down by about 50 percent.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 11, 2012
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Kings County, California, declares drought emergency
Description: On March 6, 2012, Kings County declared a drought emergency. The county is concerned about declining groundwater supplies and the low snowpack amounts in the southern Sierra Nevada (less than 30 percent of normal). NWS - Drought Information Statement - San Joaquin Valley/Hanford, California - March 8, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kings County, CA

Title: The Marin Municipal Water District in California drew about 140 acre-feet of water from the Phoenix Lake reservoir to bolster its water supply
Description: The Marin Municipal Water District drew about 140 acre-feet of water from the Phoenix Lake reservoir and transferred it to the Bon Tempe water treatment plant between March 2 and March 19.  Precipitation at nearby Lake Lagunitas was less than half of normal for the season.  Twin Cities Times (Novato, Calif.), March 7, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: The Sonoma County Water Agency in California declared the Russian River to be in “critical” supply conditions
Description: The Sonoma County Water Agency declared the Russian River to be in “critical” supply conditions.  This designation allows more water to be stored in Lake Mendocino for municipal use and for release during the fall Chinook salmon migration.  Ukiah Daily Journal (Calif.), March 1, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Whitewater rafting on hold amid drought on Kings River in California
Description: Zephyr Whitewater and Whitewater Voyages stopped river trips in 2012, due to low flows on the Kings River.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 26, 2016
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Whitewater rafting company in Fresno, California threatened by drought
Description: Four straight years of drought nearly put Kings River Expeditions, a commercial rafting company based in Fresno, out of business, but a Facebook post explaining how dire their financial situation had become brought back many guests and guides from the past to visit again.  The owner and manager of KRE explained in his post that the business averaged 1,500 customers per year during the past four years and had as few as 700 customers in 2015 when rafting ended before Memorial Day, due to low water on the Kings River.  It takes about 4,000 customers for the company to break even.  In short, the owner needed to see plenty of customers for the business to remain open.  In the two weeks following the Facebook post, they had 700 reservations for trips and the telephone keeps ringing.  In addition, the snowfall during the 2015-16 winter means that rafting should be possible through mid- to late July.Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 26, 2016
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Reduced water allocations in northern California
Description: Water districts in northern California that get water from the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation may get 75 percent of contracted water amounts for nonagricultural users and 30 percent for agricultural users, barring additional rain or snow fall this winter.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Feb. 22, 2012

Title: Farmers on the east side of the San Joaquin Valley in California were bracing for a difficult summer
Description: Farmers on the east side of the San Joaquin Valley were bracing for a difficult summer since snowfall has been about one-third of normal, meaning that farmers who rely on the San Joaquin River for water will not receive as much water as they need.  Farmers were restoring old wells, seeking to purchase water from neighbors and anticipating withdrawing water from underground water banks to eke through the summer.  They also hope for good storms in the next six weeks to deepen the snow pack and provide enough water for all activities.  This has been one of the driest winters in the past century.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), Feb. 20, 2012

Title: One chairlift at Mount Shasta Ski Park in California closed for lack of snow

Title: Ranchers in northern California concerned about water, grass for their livestock
Description: Local ranchers were concerned about water and grass for their livestock this summer, according to a north state field representative for the California Farm Bureau Federation.  Stock ponds have not refilled because there has been little runoff.  The lack of snow has left grasses very dry.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Feb. 13, 2012

Title: Olive grower irrigating weekly; rangeland grass scarce in Madera County, California
Description: Except for three days of recorded precip. in Jan 2012, there has been no rain since 11/30/12.  We are irrigating the trees and watering outside plants, and do not plan on purchasing any new plants unless the situation changes; local olive grower is irrigating weekly.  Local cattlemen are talking about selling off their cattle early; there is virtually no rangeland grass except for some growth under the trees.  Rain YTD is 5.01 out of approx 16 inches for a seasonal avg.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Yosemite Lakes 4.7 S on 2/8/2012

Description: Sales and rentals were far below normal at a ski shop in Big Bear Lake, stated the shop owner. Title: Farmer near Hemet, California replanted his wheat crop for lack of rain
Description: A farmer near Hemet had to replant his wheat crop because the seeds could not push through the crusty, dry soil.  Some of the wheat that did manage to emerge was growing slower than it normally does due to insufficient rainfall.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Jan. 30, 2012

Title: Ranchers in California's San Joaquin Valley sought alternate pastures, bought pricey hay
Description: Some farmers and ranchers had to move cattle to alternate pastures or purchase expensive hay because dry conditions have eliminated grass growth for livestock.  Hay was selling for about $300 per ton.  Some have also requested early water deliveries.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), Jan. 18, 2012

Title: Higher than normal volume of cattle sales in Fresno, California

Title: Californians’ electric bills rose  $2.45 billion from 2012 to 2016
Description: Californians’ electric bills rose a collective $2.45 billion from 2012 to 2016 as drought sharply reduced the availability of cheap hydroelectricity, estimated the Pacific Institute, an Oakland water policy think tank.  In 2016, federal data showed that Californians spent nearly $39 million on electricity Peter Gleick, the study’s author and institute’s president emeritus, noted that the loss of hydropower caused environmental impacts too.  Carbon emissions from the state’s power plants increased 10 percent during the drought as utilities reverted to conventional sources like natural gas.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 26, 2017

Title: Twice the amount of idled farmland in California's Central Valley
Description: Persistent drought in California caused farmers to fallow 1.03 million acres of land in the Central Valley, amounting to about 15 percent of the 7 million acres of irrigated farmland in the Valley, found a study undertaken by NASA, in collaboration with the United States Department of Agriculture, the United States Geological Survey, and the California Department of Water Resources.  The amount of idled land was more than twice that left idle in 2011, the most recent year with a winter of average to above average precipitation statewide.  The biggest increases in idle acreage were seen along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley in Fresno, Kings and Kern counties."These datasets highlight the continuing impacts of the drought on agricultural communities in California, and identify regions in the state that have been particularly hard hit by water shortages.  At the same time, the data provide insights into regions of the state that have been more resilient to the drought and that have been able to sustain agricultural production despite the reductions in surface water supplies," said a senior research scientist at NASA’s Ames Research Center at Moffett Field in San Jose.Central Valley Business Times (Calif.), Oct. 26, 2015

Title: Dominant species, carnivores struggled in California drought
Description: Due to drought in the Carrizo Plains of southern California between 2012 and 2015, dominant species suffered in the drought, while less dominant species benefited, found researchers from the University of Washington and the University of California, Berkeley.  Carnivores also struggled when their prey became scarce.EurekAlert! (Washington, D.C.), Aug. 20, 2018

Title: Dry conditions in California cutting the carrying capacity of pastures and rangeland, prompting producers to thin their herds
Description: Dry conditions in California are cutting the carrying capacity of pastures and rangeland, prompting producers to thin their herds.  A cattle rancher east of Fresno compared his pasture to a parking lot because not enough rain has fallen for his grass to grow.  Further west in Mariposa, Merced and Madera counties, forage production was also down, noted a University of California Cooperative Extension livestock and natural resources farm advisor.  A livestock producer in Monterey County sold about two-thirds of his herd after enduring 2012 with just a third of normal rainfall and less than a third of average forage production.  A Napa County livestock producer had little forage in 2012, due to scant rainfall, and sold all of his cattle in January 2013 rather than struggle through another dry year.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), July 9, 2013

Title: California farmers pumping more water for crop irrigation amid a fourth year of drought
Description: California farmers were pumping more water for crop irrigation amid a fourth year of drought and were using hundreds of millions of dollars more electricity than normal to power the pumps.   The co-owner of a ranch northwest of Fresno reported that their power use was two and a half times higher than normal.  In response to the higher demand for electricity, utilities were building new transmission lines and substations to support the additional electricity.  In the Central Valley, farmers may use groundwater to meet more than 60 percent of their irrigation needs in 2015, one-third more than a normal year, said a senior researcher at the University of California at Davis Center for Watershed Sciences.  At that rate, electric bills would rise 77 percent, or $600 million, compared to a year with normal precipitation.  The amount of energy needed to pump groundwater was up 90 megawatt-hours, said the senior vice president of regulatory affairs for Southern California Edison Co., a subsidiary of Edison International.   The utility built the $190 million San Joaquin Cross Valley Loop transmission project in November to meet farmers’ increased need for electricity. Pacific Gas & Electric Co. has proposed a 230-kilovolt transmission line through the Central Valley where power demand for groundwater pumping rose about 40 percent over the average levels for 2008 to 2011.The Washington Post (D.C.), Sept. 3, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Energy, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Spate of well-drilling in San Joaquin Valley, California
Description: As drought persisted and water deliveries from the state and federal projects were slim, California farmers resorted to using groundwater to keep crops growing.  In the San Joaquin Valley in 2015, farmers dug about 2,500 new wells, the most in one year and five times the annual average for the previous 30 years, according to a Sacramento Bee analysis of state and local data.  From 2012 through 2015, San Joaquin Valley farmers dug more than 5,000 wells, more than were dug altogether during the previous 12 years.  Most of the new wells were in Fresno and Tulare counties, where officials issued an average of nearly 10 agricultural well permits each business day in 2015, although some of the permits were not used.  The permit-issuing pace has slowed in the first few months of 2016, but still remained higher than pre-drought levels.  There were plenty of drilling jobs lined up for a Fresno-based well driller, who expected to drill about 260 new wells in the San Joaquin Valley in 2016.  A recent well was sunk 1,200 feet in Poplar at a cost of $260,000, although just a few years ago, the average well depth was roughly 600 feet.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 25, 2016

Title: Second year of drought takes toll on trees, landscapes, cattle ponds in Madera County, California
Description: Short on water so we are re-evaluating how much is on a drip system. Replaced pump in well last week due to excessive iron deposits; water table seemed to be stable. This is the second year of a drought--11.98 inches of rain from 7/1/12-6/30/13 (60% of normal). Oak trees are visibly stressed; leaves are in a fall-like mode--also maple trees even though they are getting watered. The lawn is a disaster--days and days of temps at or above 100 are taking their toll.  Local cattle woman says their ponds are drying up--many are not putting in pasture due to lack of water. Even tar weed, which cattle won't apparently eat, isn't blooming as it normally does. Numerous local fires since April have emitted a lot of ash into the atmosphere; unknown whether this will have an impact on the fall/winter rains.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Yosemite Lakes 4.7 S on 7/24/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Madera County, CA

Title: Drought reduced California's hydropower production
Description: The recent years of drought caused a significant lull in hydropower production, but the unusually snowy 2016-17 winter refilled reservoirs and promised to bring plenty of hydropower, possibly as much as 21 percent of the state’s total electricity output, according to the California Energy Commission.  Fifteen to 18 percent of California’s electricity generation typically comes from hydropower, according to Peter Gleick of the Pacific Institute, but during the drought, hydropower generation dropped to less than 10 percent on average.  The state turned to burning natural gas to make up the difference, driving up greenhouse gas emissions by 10 percent over what they would have been.  Burning natural gas also cost Californians $2.4 billion more than they would have paid if hydropower production had been near normal.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 20, 2017

Title: Big Bear Lake in San Bernardino County, California low after years of drought
Description: The level of Big Bear Lake in San Bernardino County went from being full in 2012 to being 13.5 feet low on May 10, 2016.  Mike Stephenson, the general manager of Big Bear Municipal Water District, stated that the lake provides water for local ski resorts’ snowmaking guns.  Years of drought also have depleted the lake.Of the decline, the general manager said, “The last four years has seen the steepest line from full to 13-and-a-half feet down that I’ve seen in recorded history.  There is no steeper line in any of the graphs that I can find.”Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 10, 2016
